subdebateinfo.title: International Financial System: Manila Framework Group

talk.start.para: â€”My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer inform the House what Australia is doing to promote confidence and stability in the international financial system? To what extent is Australia a model for other economies?

â€”I thank the honourable member for his question. Tomorrow in Melbourne Australia will be hosting and chairing a meeting of the Manila Framework Group. The Manila Framework Group is a group that was set up in response to the Asian financial crisis to put together rules which would be preventive in the future and would help countries deal their way through financial crises. Australia has taken a lead in relation to the international financial architecture, and we will be hosting this conference in Melbourne tomorrow, at which I will be making the opening speech.

answer.para: Last year the Prime Minister set up a task force on international financial reform, which I chaired, which has reported to the government. One of the recommendations that that task force made was that countries should engage in transparency reports to promote openness and understanding of their financial regulation and to benchmark themselves against international best practice. Tomorrow in Melbourne I will be releasing the first transparency report in the world. Australia has led the way, and I will be releasing this transparency report which will be regarded by the IMF as a model for other countries to adopt and to follow.

Australia's transparency report is aimed at developing best practice in our own economy in relation to financial regulation and promoting amongst our near neighbours a model which they could adopt in order to try to promote fiscal transparency in their policies as well. The IMF regards Australia's charter of budget honesty as the best international model for openness in fiscal policy. With the release of the transparency report in Melbourne tomorrow, we will again lead the world in promoting openness and understanding of policy.

As a result of the Asian financial crisis and because the Australian economy has come through this crisis in such strong health, Australia is now well placed to lead in the region and to take these steps to promote international reform. It is a leadership role which Australia has won the right to exercise and which it now has the duty to exercise. We will be leading in this way in Melbourne tomorrow.

Minister, what mechanism will you use to ensure that?

â€”Every answer that the Prime Minister gives is, of course, correct and a comprehensive response to the issues raised. The government is providing several guarantees to pensioners, including a four per cent rise in pensions up-front on 1 July 2000 and a second guarantee that the pension will remain 1.5 per cent above the CPI rise, whatever that figure may be. Pensioners will be very much better off under this government in the future as they have been in the past.
â€”Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order, and it goes to relevance.
â€”I will hear the Deputy Leader of the Opposition's point of order, but I believe the minister has concluded his answer.
â€”The minister was asked this, Mr Speakerâ€”
â€”There is no facilityâ€”

â€”Order! The Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Treasurer are being of no assistance to the chair. There is no facility for me to hear a point of order on relevance when in fact the minister has concluded his answer.
â€”Even if he hasn't answered it?
â€”The minister has answered the question.
â€”He has not answered it, Mr Speaker.
â€”The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.

â€”My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, would you inform the House of the industrial disputation figures which were released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics yesterday? How do these figures demonstrate the positive effect that the government's workplace relations changes have had in workplaces around the country?

question.para: Mr Wilton interjectingâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”I warn the member for Isaacs!

â€”I thank the honourable member for his question. The figures released yesterday by the Australian Bureau of Statistics show how the Workplace Relations Act is transforming the nature of industrial relations in Australia for the better and particularly for the benefit of employees. We saw yesterday that, for the second successive year, Australia has recorded the lowest number of working days lost per thousand employees to industrial disputes since 1913â€”1997 was the best, and 1998 is now the new record for Australia since figures were first collected back in 1913.

answer.para: This is a tremendous tribute to the effectiveness of the legislation and it really shows you that when you have a better system most people want to take a cooperative, sensible attitude to issues at work for the interests of both employees and employers. Also, it is not just the lowest number of disputes per thousand employees; it is the second lowest actual number of disputes since 1939â€”1997 is still the record, but 1998 is the second lowest actual number of disputes. So the reduction is very comprehensive right across the board.

When we first put up the Workplace Relations Act many of our critics were saying, `You might have fewer disputes, but you will have longer disputes. They will be more protracted disputes.' In fact, the opposite has been shown to be the case. So the nature of the disputes is also worth looking at. And, of course, the high levels of industrial disputes tend to be in those sectors which are highly unionised and, of course, that is often characterised by a failure of the Labor Party to speak out against disputes which cost the Australian community so dearly.

The other thing that is worth noting is that these figures do not include the bans and limitations type of industrial action. Yet we do know from anecdotal evidence that the extent of those is not what it once was either. One of the reasons for that is that we have introduced a ban on the payment of strike pay during industrial action. There is no doubt that this has affected people's behaviour. That is good for the economy as a whole, and it is also good for employees. The strike pay ban, the secondary boycott provisions that we introduced and the other compliance measures were all opposed by Labor. If Labor were ever to be re-elected, they would of course repeal all the measures which have seen such a dramatic improvement in the state of industrial relations in Australia.

Lastly, to conclude, when we advanced our policy before the 1996 election the Labor Party said, `Instead of industrial peace you will have industrial war.' And the headlines told the story: `We will go to war for pay rises, says Kelty', back in February 1996; `Kelty warns Howard: it is war over wages'; in the Canberra Times, `Union chief predicts IR war: Kelty sets his sights'; and, of course, `Crean backs wage war threat'. It is interesting to see what the acting Leader of the Opposition had to say. When asked about the prospect of industrial strife if the coalition was elected he said,
`I think they are statements of reality. You'll get interest rates up and inflation up.' `That is a recipe for economic chaos,' he predicted.

War did not break out. Peace has broken out. These are very good figures for Australian workers. The only crowd who stands in the way of the continuation of this is none other than the Labor Party, who presided over very high rates of industrial action in this country which undermined productivity and undermined the security of thousands of Australian workers.

That letter asks the Leader of the Opposition to end the uncertainty by not proceeding with the ALP's proposed disallowance motion. In conclusion, there is ample evidence in the media that I have rejected emotionalism and opportunism on this issue, be it from Labor, Green or Liberal voters. That is called a principled position. talk.start.para: â€”Would the minister tableâ€”

â€”My question is to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Does the minister stand by the Prime Minister's claim that the only GST losers will be tax cheats? Has he seen the new report of independent expert, Peter Dixon, that shows a scenario under which the GST will cost 16,000 jobs in regional New South Wales, 11,000 in regional Victoria, 12,000 jobs in regional Queensland, 2,500 jobs in regional South Australia, 1,600 jobs in regional Western Australia and 2,200 jobs in Tasmaniaâ€”a total of 45,000 jobs in areas of high unemployment.

question.para: Government members interjectingâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”The member for Dickson will come to her question.
â€”Can the minister guarantee that all of these people will not be losers under the GST?

â€”It is interesting that the opposite number in this regard is, of course, the person who facilitated the passage of Labor's increases in the indirect tax mix mess that they put up after the 1993 electionâ€”the Dawkins budget. There was no compensation then for pensioners. There was certainly no compensation for those people in rural Australia who were most affected by the increases in fuel taxâ€”
â€”Mr Speaker, on a point of order which goes to relevance: the question was specific and clearâ€”the GST package and the job losses, his comments and his guarantee.
â€”The minister will respond to the question. It was not difficult to draw a bow between what he was saying and where he was going, but he will respond to the question.
â€”I submit that the point is relevant because, in fact, their changes to the indirect tax mix did cost jobs whereas the assumption is made byâ€”
â€”On a point of order, Mr Speaker: he is defying your ruling.
â€”Order! I believe the minister was coming directly to the answer and that is why I had not intervened. If I thought he was defying the chair, clearly I would have intervened.

â€”The point really is that whilst those measures cost jobs, the assumptions made by Dixon are inappropriate. Apart from the fact that we are not hearing from the opposition the full story on this work that has been doneâ€”which does point to the prospect for increased jobs in totalityâ€”the assumptions in relation to rural industries and regional areas are made on incorrect foundations. For example, there seems to be an assumption that making Australian rural and regional export industries more competitive means that we will therefore produce too much of them, we will flood global markets, the price will come down and somehow there will be fewer jobs. I do not believe that that is realistic at all. I think the assumptions made about elasticity of demand and supply and prices here are inappropriate.

answer.para: In reality, global economic strength, international seasonal circumstances where agricultural products are concerned, the corrupt world markets that we sometimes face as a result of activities in Europe and America: these factors will have more impact on global supply and demand and price than taxation reforms here at home in Australia. The reality is that a more competitive tax system will boost exports, boost economic growth and boost jobs. That applies to rural and regional Australia as much as anywhere else.

subdebateinfo.title: Federal Republic of Yugoslavia: NATO Air Strikes

talk.start.para: â€”My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Can the minister inform the House of the Australian government's response to the decision by NATO to launch air attacks on the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia?

â€”I thank the honourable member for Hindmarsh for her question, and recognise the interest she shows in these broader international issues. These attacks by NATO on Yugoslavia are, of course, deeply regrettable, but the Australian government supports the NATO air strikes against military targets in Yugoslavia. We do regret that this action has become necessary, but there is only one person who is responsible for what has happenedâ€”that is, President Milosevic, the President of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.

answer.para: The international community cannot simply stand by and watch as President Milosevic's forces continue to perpetrate the sort of human rights abuses that have recently been perpetrated in Kosovo. It is an unreasonable proposition to expect NATO leaders to sit on their hands in that situation and do nothing.

Let me make it clear that our argument here is an argument with President Milosevic, with his government and with the instrument of his government, his armed forces. It is not an argument with the Serbian people as a whole. The tragic situation rests squarely with President Milosevic himself.

I note that President Yeltsin and others in the Russian government have recently made remarks that Russia could take military measures if the conflict grows. From the Australian government's perspective, we think that Russia should play a constructive role. For Russia to play a constructive role, President Yeltsin and other members of the Russian government, including Prime Minister Primakov, should pressure Mr Milosevic to halt his aggression and terror in Kosovo and sign up to the accord which has been negotiated at Rambouillet in France.

Finally, let me say something about those Australian citizens, many of whom have dual nationality, who are in Yugoslavia. I understand from my department that at the moment the borders of Yugoslavia still remain open, so those Australians planning to depart and who are in a position to do so should leave by the safest means available to them. Australians choosing to remain are encouraged to take the maximum protection to ensure their safety and welfare and should avoid military installations at all costs because it is the military installations which are going to be the targets of the NATO attacks.

In terms of consular services for those who are remaining, the welfare and safety of our locally engaged staff in Belgrade are obviously paramount. We have authorised them temporarily to close the embassy at short notice, should the situation warrant it. They are very dedicated people. They are prepared to provide consular assistance to Australians, but we want them to put their own safety and welfare before their professional commitment.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Wine Industry

I ask the Deputy Prime Minister: have you seen claims by the Winemakers Federationâ€”backed up by wine growers in my own electorateâ€”that, under the government's new proposed wine tax, wine prices will rise by double the rate claimed by the government and that up to 500 jobs will be lost in the wine industry? â€”I am delighted to get a question, having put in an hour's extra preparation today for this, the 204th question time since the government changed; and you guys have learned nothing in terms of tactics over that period of time.
â€”The Deputy Prime Minister will come to the question.

â€”The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!

Mr Brian Croser, President of the Winemakers Federation, told a select committee hearing in Adelaide that the results of the modelling showed that under our tax packageâ€”the coalition's better tax system tax reform packageâ€”everyone wins in relation to the wine industry. I quote:

answer.para: Under an ad valorem system, which is a continuation of the current system, the non-premium wine sector benefits more than the premium wine sector, but both sectors benefit under a GST plus, in effect, wine equalisation tax arrangements.

We are about helping export industry. We are about helping to give them a competitive basis, which we will do under our system, so that they can push forward with their export effort to the world. subdebateinfo.title: Centrelink: Cyclones and Floods in Western Australia

talk.start.para: â€”My question is addressed to the Minister for Community Services. Can the minister inform the House what action Centrelink is taking for victims of floods and cyclones in Western Australia?

â€”I thank the honourable member for her question. I am sure all members are dismayed at the extent of the damage that has been caused in Western Australia. Fortunately there has been no loss of life, but there has been considerable damage from the cyclone and flooding in Western Australia. As has been reported to the House earlier today, the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition, along with the member for Kalgoorlie, are visiting those areas at the present time.

answer.para: Mr Haase has been very active in representing the needs of the people of his area in this time of tragedy. Centrelink has been quick to move to assist the people who are in need. I am told that in Exmouth there are some 780 homes, of which 112 have been destroyed. In all, around two-thirds of all the housing in the town has been seriously damaged or destroyed. So there is considerable need for prompt assistance.

Centrelink has 10 staff at the Noalimba centre in Bateman to care for those who have been evacuated from the Moora area and to offer assistance to the victims. They are also providing counselling. Centrelink counsellors are available both there and to assist the people at Exmouth to deal with the emergency and to provide emergency assistance as required. Centrelink Carnarvon is the local office for the Exmouth people. It is fully operational. It is attending to the needs of the people, ensuring that emergency assistance is available promptly to all of those who need it.

There have been a number of emergencies around Australia over recent weeks. I would like to pay tribute to the Centrelink staff who have kept their offices open, often in very difficult circumstances, to meet the needs of and to care for people in these emergency situations. In Cairns, North Queensland, in Gympie in the electorate of the honourable member for Fairfax, coming in across the floods, many Centrelink staff have left their own homes behind to make sure that essential government services were provided. These people are real heroes, just as are those who are involved in rescue. I would like to congratulate the Centrelink staff who have put so much effort into Moora and Exmouth to make sure that the victims of these tragedies are receiving their benefits and the sort of care and assistance that they need at this time.

Another development has been that, with the outbreak of disease in Malaysia, Singapore has closed off its borders to pork from Malaysia. The Singaporean market is worth about 100,000 tonnes of pork a year. What the government is doing in improving the capacity, the viability and the competitiveness of Australia's pork industry is absolutely the correct thing to do to help develop a modern export oriented pork industry in Australia. We are proving that with the marketplaces that are being opened up all over the world.
â€”Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The minister was reading from a statement and I ask him to table the ministerial statement he was reading from.
â€”The minister was not reading and is not therefore required to table the statement.
â€”The Minister for Defence and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition will exercise the sort of restraint Australia would expect from them.

â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Is the minister aware of the options paper currently being considered which includes the proposal from your government's Commission of Audit that the Australian Red Cross blood service be commercialised by having its government grants abolished and a price put on every litre of blood supplied to hospitals? Will the minister commit to continuation in full of Commonwealth grants for the blood bank to continue as a voluntary community service? Will the minister rein in the Victorian Premier, who is actively pushing this proposal? Will the minister ensure that patients are not charged for each litre of blood provided?
â€”I am not aware of the options paper that the shadow minister raises.

â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation. In relation to the recent benefits that he has told us about with developing Australia as a centre for global financial services, do such developments have any implication for the export of Australian financial services into the Asian region?

â€”I can report information that would be pleasing to the Deputy Prime Ministerâ€”that is, that financial exports have more than doubled over the last five years. In part, that is attributable to the Asian financial crisis which has led to South-East Asian countries requesting Australian support in relation to corporate restructuring, accounting and legal services, debt recovery, financial forecasting and merger and acquisition activity. I can also report that Australian regulatory authorities such as the Australian Securities and Investments Commission, the RBA, the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the ACCC and APRA are all playing a role in the region. They are up there providing regulatory advice and services to the region in assisting the region to rebuild the regulatory framework that will help it recover from the Asian financial crisis.

answer.para: We must build on these existing relationships. I am very pleased to observe that AMP has announced a strategic link with the Unit Trust of India. The Unit Trust of India is no minnow in the provision of financial services. It has $US15 billion in funds under management. It has 50 million customer accounts and it manages more than six offshore funds. AMP and the Unit Trust of India have indicated that they are developing a $US500 million infrastructure fund that will assist with the construction of power generation facilities, transport, oil, gas and telecommunications facilities in India. This follows on the successful activities of other financial institutions in the Asian region such as Macquarie Bank, the Australia-New Zealand Banking Corporation, AMP, NAB, GIO, QBE, Westpac and many others.

If we are seeking to be a financial centre for the region, it is important that we provide the world with access to the Asian region without the risks of the region. That can be best facilitated by actively participating in the region and encouraging Australian financial institutions to be more involved in the financial recovery of Asia.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. answer.para: Mr Bevis interjectingâ€”

â€”The point I make, Mr Speakerâ€”

answer.para: Mr Adams interjectingâ€”

â€”The point I make is that, if you are a body corporate today and you are subject to state industrial laws but you wish to use the federal system for agreement making, there is nothing to stop you. That happens today. That was part of the Workplace Relations Act. In terms of the policy position of the New South Wales state opposition, there have been various statements by members of the state opposition in New South Wales over the years. The statements they make are a matter for them. Our policy position has been to have a simpler system by encouraging harmonisation between the two systems.

answer.para: The question today of the member for Brisbane is like his inane press release of yesterday. It was inane. Even ACTU President Jennie George said, `On the face of it, Mr Reith's proposal to allow the commission to make common rule awards which applied to all workers in an industry may be helpful.' Leigh Hubbardâ€”he is not exactly on our side, is he?â€”also said, `On the face of it, it sounds good.' He qualified the statement, but at least he was prepared to say, `Well, here's an idea. Let's talk about it.' Andrew Murray, a senator for the Democrats, was quoted in the AAP as saying:
. . . some parts of the plan could be supported.
Senator Murray also agreed with Mr Reith that the system could cover the entire community.

He then went on to make some positive comments. If you are going to be a frontbencher, whether on this side or the other side, you do have to have a capacity to understand the issues and to have a considered response to sensible proposals. It is not just a problem for you that you are a former trade union official. The fact is that you do not even understand how the system operates today. It is no wonder you have no policies and it is no wonder you are such a pushover for the trade union leadership.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Community Services. Would the minister please explain to the House the benefits that the assistance to the carers amendment bill will provide for Australian carers?

â€”This government is committed to carers in ensuring that they receive the support they need in caring for people with disabilities, particularly elderly Australians and children. In every budget since this government has come to office, there have been initiatives to provide benefits for carers and care recipients. In particular, the $280 million staying at home package announced in April 1998 provided tremendous benefits to carers. The assistance to the carers amendment bill will help another 14,000 Australian carers and result in a simpler and more consistent system for assessing entitlements. These changes reflect the government's commitment to providing a better deal for carers and to ensuring that they have support in undertaking their important task.

answer.para: The government proposes that the carers allowance combine two existing paymentsâ€”the child disability allowance for carers of children up to 16 years and the domiciliary nursing care benefit for carers of adults 16 years of age or older. These benefits will take effect from July 1999. There will be no income test, and they will not be subject to taxation. So these are real benefits. There will also be greater flexibility in ensuring that the benefits continue during periods when people are temporarily in hospital. I thank the honourable member for Hughes for her question and for her continuing interest in the needs of carers and those people in her community with disabilities, those people who need some support to ensure that in spite of their disability they are able to live in the community with the best possible care.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

â€”After the 204th question time, I would like to add to an answer given during question time by providing the House with some additional information in which members might be interested. The first full shipment, as the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has correctly indicated, of chilled pork to Singapore is going ahead with a major promotion this month. I was very pleased to see that trial shipment on the supermarket shelves of Singapore and the very good consumer response it attracted, the buyer success. It proved to be a very popular new market for the Australian pork industry. It augurs well for future export and jobs for the Australian pork industry.

â€”Thank you, Mr Speaker. I have been consistent on this issue. It is the member for Higgins who seems to have changed his mind on this topic.

Dr KEMP

talk.start.para: â€”Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
â€”Does the minister claim to have been misrepresented?
â€”I do.

speech.para: Opposition members interjectingâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Please proceed. I remind those on my left that the minister is entitled to precisely the same protection as I endeavoured to provide for the member for Melbourne Ports.
â€”The member for Melbourne Ports has claimed that I misrepresented what he said in the article entitled `Compulsory student unions: Australia's forgotten closed shop'. I table the article.

A minister can always add to an answer and table a document, but a member rising on a personal explanation has a responsibility to you and the House to show where he has been misrepresented. It is an abuse of the forms of the House.

â€” I have received a letter from the honourable member for Wills proposing that a definite matter of public import ance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

interjection.para: The negative effect of the government's proposed GST and other policies on employment throughout Australia.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their placesâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Being one of the more technologically challenged members of the House, I had to rely on my staff to get for me from the parliamentary web site the explanatory memorandum for the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Strategic Investment Program Bill 1999. But, having obtained that memorandum, I was very surprised when reading it to find that a number of sentences had been crossed out and, in looking further, I found that they did not appear on the version of the explanatory memorandum which was circulated to members of the House. So I had a closer look at some of the sentences which had been altered or crossed out to see what might have given rise to this.

speech.para: I draw to the attention of the House, first, the sentence which said, `It is not possible to easily establish the full costs of the strategic investment program.' That sentence had been deleted and replaced by, `The overall cost to revenue is $700 million.' You have to ask yourself what sort of faith you might have in a figure like that which apparently has just been plucked from the air.

Even more seriously, I went on to note that the sentence which read, `The implementation of the Strategic Investment Program may contribute to further losses in employment as a result of increased efficiencies due to capitalisation as well as rationalisation,' had been completely deleted from the tabled version of the explanatory memorandum. Then on page 14 I saw the sentence, `The Strategic Investment Program addresses the regional elements of the loss of employment; under this program targeted assistance will be provided to retrenched regional TCF employees.' The government did not want any reference to retrenched regional TCF employ ees appearing, so that reference had disappeared.

Again, on page 16, there was a reference to `skills upgrading for displaced TCF employees'. That was too sensitive. That had disappeared as well. Finally, on that page there reference is made to the 2005 review of assistance for TCF, and the dot point concerning the need for further assistance for the TCF industries had been deleted from the explanatory memorandum too. So the government does not want to send out a message that that 2005 review might consider the need for further assistance for the TCF industries.

Had it not been for the government's blunder in posting both the initial and revised explanatory memorandum on the Internet, we may never have become aware that the industry department believes that the government's plan will lead to job losses and regional retrenchments in the TCF industries. I suppose we can get some wry amusement at the prospect of some bureaucratic butt being kicked as a result of this gaff, but it does have a much more sinister side.

It is clear that these changes were made to protect the Prime Minister from embarrassment over the announcement he made back in September 1997 at the Bonds factory in the electorate of Parramatta. There the Prime Minister referred to `a decision that will promote job security'. He went on to say:
This is a very good decision for the battlers of Australia. It is a decision which is designed to give people a greater sense of job security.
And later again:
It will result in jobs being saved in the industry.

Certainly, the Prime Minister would have had considerable egg over his face if that explanatory memorandum had come out in that form referring to the prospect of job losses in the TCF industries as a result of the government's plan.

Frankly, we deserve better than this. The Prime Minister made a covenant with the people of Australia talking about standards of honesty, standards of integrity. Instead, what we get is this kind of attempt at cover-up. We are entitled to a full explanation from the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources as to who doctored these sentences, and on whose authority it was done. In the meantime, the government stands condemned for attempting to conceal from this parliament and from the people of Australia the real job costing impact of its policies for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries.

This was not the only cat that got out of the jobs bag this week. I take the House back to the findings of Professor Peter Dixon of Monash University earlier this year, when he reported to the Senate inquiry into the GST that `the GST is job destroying'. He said that the extent of the job destruction could reach 100,000, with tourism and exports of education being hit hardest. He went on to say that there will be no long-term boost to economic growth from the tax package. And this came at a time when the Treasury had to admit to that inquiry that they had done no modelling of the impact of the GST concerning jobs and that their GST modelling assumed no increase in employment.

At the same time, we had the new head of the Business Council of Australiaâ€”one of those enthusiastic supporters of the GSTâ€”saying that he could not say whether the GST would create or destroy jobs. The evidence of that time from Professor Dixon was that the GST would cost jobs. He said, `Why would you bother with a tax like this that is only going to cost jobs?'

In addition to that, we had the modelling of Chris Murphy, whom the government is very fond of, indicating to the Master Builders Association the prospect of long-term job losses in the housing industry of 2.4 per centâ€”that against the optimistic background that he had made no allowance for the extra GST paperwork burden for the 1.5 million extra businesses caught in the GST net. Mr Murphy indicated to the Senate inquiry that Queensland and Tasmania will face job losses arising from the government's tax package, which of course must be a matter of interest to Senators Colston and Harradine.

If you actually look at where the greatest number of job losses are going to occur, it turns out that they are in New South Wales. I was intrigued today to notice that the government, in the final question time before the New South Wales election, saw fit to ask not one dorothy dixer in support of their side at the forthcoming election. In every question time I have been here prior to a state election, this government have asked dorothy dixers designed to support their own side. In the case of Kerry Chikarovski, they have decided she is beyond recall, so they are not interested in asking anything that might support her.
Mr Leo McLeay interjectingâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Indeed.
â€”The member for Wills does not need the help of the member for Watson.

â€”Perhaps New South Wales voters might be interested to learn that, in the case of the tourism industry, the Tourism Task Force has estimated that some 59,000 jobs will be lost following the introduction of a GST and, of those jobs, over 19,500 are expected to be lost in New South Wales. That is a bigger share of those job losses than any other state. Similarly, we now find Professor Dixon, from the Centre of Policy Studies at Monash University, released modelling this week concerning the short-run implications for employment of the government's tax package broken down by industry, region, occupation and so on. If we look at those, we find that the most severe impact is in New South Wales.

speech.para: Under the scenario Professor Dixon puts forward, whereby workers seek and obtain some wage rise based on extra costs they will incur as a result of the GSTâ€”and let me say the government has made the heroic assumption that it believes workers will not seek any kind of wage compensation for the GST based price risesâ€”the GST will cost over 40,000 jobs in New South Wales. Of those, 26,800 jobs will be lost in the Sydney area, over 3,000 in the Hunter region, over 2,000 in the Illawarra region, 1,400 in the Richmond-Tweed region, 1,800 on the mid North Coast of New South Wales and over 1,400 in south-eastern New South Wales. I think some New South Wales voters might like to reflect on that when they go to the polls on Saturday and send the same message to Prime Minister Howard as they sent back in October when they, like a majority of other Australians, indicated that they did not support a GST.

The GST according to this scenario will cost 16,000 jobs in regional New South Wales, 11,000 in regional Victoria, 12,000 in regional Queensland, 2,500 in regional South Australia, 1,600 in regional Western Australia and 2,200 in Tasmania. So there will be a very severe impact on the wellbeing of people in regional Australia, whom this government claims to have an interest in.

We also see from the modelling of Professor Dixon a severe impact in areas such as health and education. Over 1,000 nurses, 600 GPs, 400 occupational therapists and many others in the health area will lose their jobs, while primary school teachers, secondary school teachers, university lecturers, library workers and the like will lose their jobs in the education area.

We also discovered this week a little more about the impact of the GST on the wine industry. Yesterday the government announced its legislation concerning the wine industry. The wine industry's response to this was that they would lose some 500 jobs as well as 8,000 tonnes of grape productionâ€”equivalent to a wine region the size of the Adelaide Hills and more than even my colleagues could cope with, I suspect. It would be a very severe loss to the wine industry as a result of the government's GST legislation.

If we look at other industries, there is a similar unsatisfactory pattern. Even on the government's rosy, most optimistic scenario, we find that employment in the mining area will fall by more than one per cent and employment in agriculture will fall by over two per cent. There will be net job losses as well in forestry and fishing; food, drink and tobacco; textile, clothing and footwear; chemical products; electricity, gas and water; transport; communication; and entertainmentâ€”all those sectors face the prospect of job losses if the GST is successful. This is against a background where the government's job record is far from satisfactory.

Over the course of the last three years, the Howard government has averaged employment growth of less than 11,000 per month. Under Labor over its last three years, that figure was over 20,000 per month. Similarly, long-term unemployment has gone up by over 10,000 since that change of government occurred.
Dr Kemp interjectingâ€”
Mr Crean interjectingâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”The minister and the member for Hotham will both be silent. The member for Wills has the call.

â€”Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. While the Prime Minister says there can be no serious addressing of unemployment without a GST, the truth is that a GST is all about this government and this party's traditional agenda of shifting wealth from those who are less well-off towards those who are already well-off. What this is intended to achieve is income tax cuts, the overwhelming majority of whichâ€”over 50 per cent of themâ€”will go to the top 20 per cent of income earners. The wealthiest 20 per cent in this country will get over 50 per cent of the tax cuts. So what the government is endeavouring to do with its GST is shift the tax burden on to the poor by imposing that tax on just about everything. That is the approach this government has taken to unemployment all the way through.

speech.para: It has either had useless gimmicks of the kind, `We'll set up a committee,' as the Prime Minister announced back in October 1996, or `We'll have a special meeting,' as he announced in Townsville in 1997, or the government's agenda of shifting money away from those who are less well off towards those who are already well off. In 1996, they said, `Pass our 1996 budget.' It was passed and, indeed, unemployment went up. It is what they say in relation to minimum wages. They say, `Let us cut minimum wages and that will do something about unemployment.' Once again, that is simply about making the rich richer and the poor poorer.

We are going to continue to oppose this government's agenda concerning GST. We understand the revelations this week that it will not provide any more jobs for Australians. Indeed, in all those sectors critical to the health of our economy it will have an adverse effect on jobs and we will oppose it accordingly.

talk.start.para: â€”You have to give Labor credit at least for their audacity. For the vandals of the labour market to come in here and raise an MPI on unemployment is just mind-boggling. On economic management, they fail dismally. On policy development, they score a zero. But on hypocrisy, on audacity, on hide, they score 100 per cent. This is absolute hypocrisy and nonsense.

speech.para: Again, Labor leads with their chin by inviting reminders of their own dismal performance on the issue of jobs. Let me remind the member opposite that during Labor's 13 years unemployment averaged 8.7 per cent. It peaked at 11.2 per cent in December 1992 when their then Prime Ministerâ€”I might add with the support of many of the members currently on the opposition front benchâ€”engineered a recession that had close to a million Australians out of work. Labor's only approach was to throw more money at the problem, to create a meaningless merry-go-round of labour market programs that did little more than hide the extent of the problem. Labor's billion dollar bandaid program did nothing to cure the problem; it just held out false hopes to the unemployed.

By contrast, under coalition management over the last three years over 406,000 new jobs have been created and unemployment has fallen to 7.4 per cent. We had an average of 8.7 per cent for 13 years of Labor and, alreadyâ€”after three years of coalition governmentâ€”we are down to 7.4 per cent. And this is at a time when the participation rate has actually risen from the average of 62.4 per cent under Labor to 63.3 per cent now. The point is, under the coalition government, not only are more people working but more people are coming into the job market because they know there are jobs there. Under Labor they had given up. There was no chance; there was no hopeâ€”the participation rate was down and unemployment was up. Under the coalition government, in just three years, the participation rate has risen, hope has risen and employment has risenâ€”406,000 new jobs in the last three years.

It is also worth pointing out that under this government not only are there more people in jobs but those people who are in jobs are better off than they were under Labor. For 13 years under Labor real wage growth averaged a paltry half a percentâ€”0.5 per cent. Already in the last three years under this government real wages growth has averaged 2.5 per cent a year. Under the coalition we have more people in work, we have more people in the job market because they are confident of getting jobs and we have real wage growth that is, on average, per annum, five times as high as it was under Labor in their miserable 13 years.

Added to that are the figures we have just had released this week showing that under this government we have had the lowest level of industrial disputes per thousand workers that we have had for decades. So we have a more content work force, a better paid work force and a work force that has more people in jobs than we had for 13 years of hard labour.

It is also worth pointing out that young people are benefiting from jobs growth under this government. Youth unemployment has fallen from 27.2 per cent that we inherited from Labor to 23.5 per cent. It has fallen from the outrageous 34.9 per cent that they gave us in 1992. For young people this government has provided a record number of apprenticeships and traineeshipsâ€”123,160 commencements last year alone. We have a record number of apprenticeships and a record level of hope for young people. Labor left office with the lowest number of apprenticeships and traineeships in 30 years, and this government has already reached a record number in just three short years.

This government's performance on employment is a result of sound economic management that creates sustainable growth based on private sector investment, not on a stop-start cycle of excessive spending that we had under Labor. The bust-boom sort of mentality that they had was unsustainable. The jobs growth we have had under this government is the result of sound economic management. It is a result of increasing motivation and increasing incentive in the work force. It is a result of carefully targeted labour market programs. It is a result of increased spending on vocational education and training. It is a result of increased spending on literacy and numeracy that in the long term will also have a positive impact. It is absolute nonsense and hypocrisy for Labor to come in here and give us the rubbish that we have just heard for the last 15 minutes from the member for Wills.

On the specific question of the Dixon model that the member for Wills raised, this is the basis of Labor's limp-wristed criticism of the government's tax package. Typically, it is simplistic, selective and misleading. The member for Wills has done what his colleagues always doâ€”selectively chosen material that will mislead, that will deceive and might somehow give an appearance of substance to their case.

Not surprisingly, the Labor dominated committee chose their preferred modeller, Peter Dixon, to analyse the effects of the Monash model. The point that the member for Wills failed to mention is that the shortcomings of the Dixon model, which he so heavily relied on, were comprehensively outlined to the Senate select committee in January this year. In particular, the Dixon analysis wrongly assumes that workers will bargain for wage rises as a result of the tax changes.
Mr Kelvin Thomson interjectingâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Order! The member for Wills!

â€”That was the whole basis of their argument. It ignoresâ€”and the member for Wills would even know this, if he admitted itâ€”the greater disposable income they will have as a result of the tax cuts. This is totally unrealistic nonsense. They will have higher take-home pay because of the income tax cuts, yet the Dixon model on which Labor depends tries to somehow argue that, with more money in their pocket, higher real wages, they will still be wanting to push for wage rises.

speech.para: Even Dixon himself in his model assumes that there will be real after-tax pay rises. In fact, his figures were these. Dixon's model itself shows ongoing real after-tax pay risesâ€” plus 0.6 in year one, 0.7 per cent in year two, 0.8 per cent in year three, 0.9 per cent in year four, one per cent in year five, one per cent in year six and one per cent in year seven. For seven years there will be rises in after-tax real wages, according to Dixon himself. The member for Wills should go back and read what he had to say.
Mr Kelvin Thomson interjectingâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Order! The member for Wills!

â€”The Dixon model also ignores the fact that low income earners and welfare recipients will be better off because of increased government benefits as a result of the government's tax proposal. The Dixon model also ignores the fact that international experience shows that, with the implementation of a GST in countries such as New Zealand, Canada and Japan, there was no wages blow-out at all. Econtech says that a wages blow-out is quite unlikely because workers are better off than in the base wage case simulation. In fact, Econtech said we might more likely get wage restraint rather than a wages blow-out, yet Labor's whole case is based on the theoretical possibility of a wages blow-out.

speech.para: Econtech, in its report of 14 February, said that `the chance of ANTS producing a wages blow-out are remote'. The member for Wills again selectively quoted Chris Murphy earlier on. Mr Murphy also noted in his evidence and his report that the positive employment effects arising out of these models was likely to be an underestimate because they could not capture the employment gains that would occur from the alleviation of the poverty trap.

There were many other shortcomings in the Dixon model that I will not go into now except just to briefly say that it included none of the potential positive effects on savings, none of the positive externalities from higher investment, none of the effects of lower marginal tax rates on efficiency and unemployment, and none of the benefits of reducing the complexity and administrative inefficiency of the current ramshackle tax system. And it underestimated by some $100 million to $150 million, according to Econtech, the economic welfare gains of these tax changes. In other words, the Dixon model on which Labor are basing their paltry case ignores many of the benefits that will flow as a result of this tax reform package. Yet this does not stop Labor. It does not stop them relying on inaccuracy, on deceit and on misleading models. They will clutch at any straw to try to mount a case.

The argument by Labor also ignores other research and other models. The research undertaken by the Melbourne Institute showed that tax changes could increase the number of jobs long term by 50,000â€”an increase of 50,000 jobs. Access Economics goes even further. Access Economics, in their AEM model forecast of December last year, indicated that, as a result of the tax changes, 190,000 new jobs would be created in the long term.

Two other points need to be mentioned. As a result of this tax package, business costs will fall by $10 billion and the cost to exporters will fall by $4Â½ billion. Treasury estimates that GDP growth will be at least 0.5 per cent extra per annum, and many other models argue up to two per cent per annum extra in real GDP. What do you get, Mr Thomson, when GDP grows? You get job growth, you get employment growth, you get more people working. Even the member for Wills would understand that.
Mr Kelvin Thomson interjectingâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Order! The member for Wills will be silent and the member for Macquarie will address his remarks through the chair.

â€”Sadly, but predictably, Labor are well wide of the mark again. It is also worth pointing out, in the context of Labor's argument about employment, two other important issues. One is their refusal to back down from their ridiculous, job destroying unfair dismissal lawsâ€”the fact that they are refusing to give small business the chance to employ the young people that they would like to employ. It is estimated that another 50,000 jobs, particularly for young people, would be generated if Labor just had a short-term dose of commonsense and stood asideâ€”

speech.para: Mr Kelvin Thomson interjectingâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Order! The honourable member for Macquarie will resume his seat. If I can get the attention of and some eye contact with the member for Wills, I would like to tell him and instruct him that he does not have to be a Greek chorus and keep up a running comment on everything the other members say. Please be silent.

â€”The member for Wills obviously does not like to hear the facts. The fact is that 50,000 jobs would be created almost immediately if the unfair dismissal laws were allowed through. An interesting anecdote: just after the minister passed those regulations at the end of last year, I had a small businessman in my office talking about another issue. He said on his way out, `By the way, congratulate the minister, Peter Reith, for me. I'm going to go out and put on an apprentice.' That was after the regulations went through. Those regulations subsequently were overturned by the opposition, who are intent on destroying jobs, not on creating jobs.

speech.para: The other point that needs to be made is this: Labor's head in the sand, obstructionist approach to youth wages is also destructive of jobs. The government is trying to create jobs; the opposition is trying to destroy jobs. The Retail Traders Association estimates that, if the abolition of youth wages goes ahead, as Labor and the Democrats want, in retail alone 170,000 to 180,000 jobs could be lost. Throughout industry generally, some 230,000 jobs could be lost as a result of their obstructionist determination and their determination to abolish youth wages. This is a disgrace. Labor is more interested in its own political future than it is in the future of the unemployed. It is more dominated by union demands than by sound policy judgment.

I will go back to the issue of the impact of the tax package on jobs and make a couple of other points. I quote the executive director of one of my local chambers of commerce. This is what he said towards the end of last year:
If I could have a wish, it would be that somehow we could just put aside political bias and just assess the facts of the matter:
Member for Willsâ€”just assess the facts of the matter.

A GST will dramatically LOWER the cost of running businesses, because we subtract the GST paid out, from the GST collected . . . It's time to fix this tax system and restore the incentive to have a business, create jobs and improve the standard of living for all honest Australians.

This tax package is about creating incentive for small business. It is about encouraging the promotion of jobs. It is about giving young people and older people a chance. It is about creating job security for those who are already working. It is about giving opportunities and creating possibilities for those who do not yet have a job. The coalition's record on this is secure. The coalition's record is that we have been creating jobs. We can continue to create jobs if Labor will stand aside, will stop their petty politics and will allow us to get on with the job that we were elected to do. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â€”When it comes to matters of public importance they do not come much more important than this one. I can see the negative effect of the government's proposed GST and other policies on employment throughout Australia. It is a matter of paramount importance to every one of us in the Australian Labor Party but, more than that, it is at the heart of so many of the problems facing the communities and families we work with and represent.

speech.para: The government would know that if the Prime Minister and his Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business stopped preening themselves in front of the businessmen's clubs in Sydney and Melbourne and spent time in regional Australia. If, for example, members of the government spent some time at a meatworks where the workers fear for their jobs, health and safety without proper award protection, in a town where the last bank just closed its doors, or at a Centrelink officeâ€”I mean a real Centrelink office, not a stage-managed oneâ€”where staff cuts mean the unemployed struggle to get an appointment let alone the kind of support and attention they need to seize employment opportunities, they would know more about the impact of their policies. But whether or not they would care is another question.

Members of the government obviously do not spend too much time thinking about the problem of unemployment. If they did they would not be carrying on with the arrogance and smugness that we have to put up with here every day and that Australians have to put up with every time they watch the news or open a paper. What a great opportunity this is to get behind the government's arrogance and rhetoric and to talk about the damage being done to our communities as a result of this government's failure to provide solutions for the unemployedâ€”whether they be the young unemployed, the hidden mature aged unemployed people who have been discouraged from even looking for work or the shamefully high 220,000 long-term unemployed that the government continues to leave on the scrap heap.

When this opportunity to speak on the MPI came up today the whip was fighting us off with a stick, because I know that every one of my colleagues feels as strongly about this issue as I do. For those of us on this side of the House everything relates back to employment and, as far as we are concerned, the employment impacts of every policy or bill should be at the top of the agenda and form part of every debate. Why is that? It is because we know that, whatever issue comes up, all we will hear from the government is `profits, competition, deregulation and some bigger profits'. It is left to the Labor members to ask, `Will this create employment? Does it lead to opportunities for growth and employment in regional areas, including those on the edges of our large cities? Does it encourage people to improve their skills and provide the means for them to learn new skills?'

The government does not apply itself to those fundamental questions, and the results of that uninterest speak for themselves. First of all, 700,000 people in Australia are currently unemployed. That is an absolute disgrace. Even worse is the government's failure to take any responsibility for those people or for their hopes for finding employment. A government that recognised some obligation to combat unemployment would not be putting a new tax on our job creating service industries like tourism and hospitality, or a new tax on education, on training, on job search services and on the services provided by group training companies that are so important to apprentices and businesses in regional areas.

In the period February 1996 to February 1999 unemployment has been reduced by less than 70,000. The average growth in employment per month under this government has been less than 11,000. When you compare that to the achievements of Labor in our last three years of government you want to cry for the lost opportunities this government is responsible for. Our record in our last three years of government was over 20,000 new jobs a month. That is a difference of 9,000 jobs a month. Doesn't that figure make you angry? I just think of what it would have done for the young people and families in my community if we had been getting our share of those 9,000 jobs a month over the last three years. How many kids could not afford to go on school excursions? How many relationships broke up under the strain of financial pressures, and how many people missed out on valuable skills for their future because of those 9,000 missing jobs in this country each month?

In the same period the rate of people participating in the labour market actually fell from 63.8 per cent in 1996 at the end of Labor's term to 63.1 per cent in February 1999. A significant part of this is a result of people becoming disillusioned and leaving the labour market. Does the government ever stop to think where those people have gone, what they are doing or how they are ever going to get back into employment once they have given up the active search for employment and training opportunities?

When Labor was in government we correctly regarded the participation rate as an equally important measure of the success of our employment initiatives. We were about getting people into employment not simply about getting people off the unemployment statistics. There is a very big difference. A drop-off in unemployment is meaningless if it really represents a dropping out.

As a member representing a regional seat, I know that the unemployment figures are yet one more example confirming what we in regional and rural areas already knowâ€”the Howard government has well and truly abandoned us. Whatever meagre growth there has been in employment in Australia has been very unevenly distributed. The government has to take responsibility for the hole left behind in our regional communities. Realistically, we are not going to get a piece of the boardroom action in the capital cities without a serious effort from government.

You can see this in the unemployment figures in February 1999: places like the Hunter which registered 11.4 per cent unemployment; Richmond-Tweed, 15.4 per cent, the central highlands of Victoria, 10.3 per cent; and Queenslandâ€”for example, Darling Downsâ€”showing 9.1 per cent unemployment. This government is just not fair dinkum about creating jobs and opportunities in Australia's regionsâ€”those in rural areas as well as those in metropolitan centres. Work for the Dole is nowhere near enough. We need a comprehensive plan for regional development. We need a government working with local communities to identify strengths and opportunities for particular regionsâ€”in particular, looking at the essential interaction between education, training, labour market programs and regional development incentives. Instead, this government comes up with nothing more than gimmicks.

They have had three years to work on answers to unemployment and we have yet to see one new idea emerge that has any answers for creating employment and building a highly skilled work force. The Job Network has failed the long-term unemployed and has failed regional and rural Australia. The rate of long-term unemployment has fallen by less than 20,000 since the Job Network was introduced and, over the last three years since the government slashed the labour market programs that Labor introduced, long-term unemployment has increased by over 10,000 people. When you look at the figures from around some of the regions in Australia it is obvious that the Job Network cannot get results in areas of high unemployment.

The figures for teenage unemployment are really frightening in places like Far North Queensland which has jumped from 13.4 per cent in 1996 to 34.4 per cent in 1999. The figure for Canterbury-Bankstown in Sydney has increased from 17.1 to 33.8 per cent. Where is the hope for these young people?

talk.start.para: â€”It is a disgrace.
â€”What is it?

â€”A disgrace. When you look at the figures from around some of the regions, it is obvious that they are not getting results. The only new idea we have heard about for the last year is the GST; and it is a job-destroyer for regional Australia. Professor Peter Dixon's report to the Senate select committee inquiry shows the disastrous impact that the GST will have on the industries that are the lifeline of our rural and regional areas. There is not much good news in here for anyone in Capricornia. Agriculture, losing over 5,000 jobs, mining, losing 141 jobs in the coalmining sector, and textiles, clothing and footwear are all industries predominantly located in the regional areas that are struggling under high rates of unemployment.

speech.para: There is not much in there for anyone representing regional seats to be very pleased about. As a Queenslander, the impact of the GST is horrifying when you look at the potential job losses projected for the tourism industry. In its submission to the Senate inquiry into the GST, the Tourism Task Force has worrying conclusions for people looking for work in any sector of the tourism industry. Their prediction is that total employment losses, due to falling tourist spending in Australia, amounted to 59,500 jobs. And we are supposed to vote for this GST when you talk about those sort of figures. It is unbelievable.

Those are the job losses that this government is setting us up for, if it continues with the GST. When Peter Reith spoke to the Press Club yesterday about Australians choosing the rate of unemployment, he was acknowledging the truth. Australians did choose lower unemployment when over half the country voted last October to reject the GST. It is the government that is pushing ahead with what it has chosen for Australiaâ€”an acceptance of high unemployment and higher living costs under the GST.

talk.start.para: â€”I note that my colleague and neighbour the member for Capricornia said, `When it comes to matters of public importance, they do not come any more important than this.' It is interesting to note that the member for Wills, the shadow assistant Treasurer, initiated this MPI and I suppose that, in itself, has ramifications for the shadow Treasurer. He still has not made one major speech on the economy in this place.

speech.para: The MPI itself is clearly another token show of support for the policy of the Leader of the Opposition of continuing to oppose tax reformâ€”and, for that matter, just about everything elseâ€”while at selected forums he upturns Labor policy for a temporary populist position. There is no greater one than this, that having vehemently opposed a change to youth wages here in the parliament he then goes and supports the shop assistants union in doing the very same thing. He is certainly under a lot of pressure from within his own party. It must damage his leadership still further to have the former ALP national secretary telling him his policies are wrong and that he should support our tax reform package or move to a country that is backward enough to accept his policies. There are some countries like this that have retained the wholesale sales tax systemâ€”Botswana, Swaziland, Pakistan and the Solomon Islands. No doubt Mr Hogg was referring to one of these.

I am surprised that the Labor Party continues to argue that the tax reform package will have a negative impact on employment, given the evidence that is against that premise. It must be hard for intelligent members opposite to go along with this policy of denial. Let us look at the evidence on the tax reform that will come from the GST and economic growth. The economists Salomon Smith Barney predicted that tax reform would lift GDP by 2.3 per cent. Econtech indicated a long run GDP gain of around two per cent with the replacement of a wholesale sales tax with a VAT. The Melbourne Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research model was used and adopted by ACOSS. In its submission to the Senate, ACOSS could prove no class of person was worse off. The Melbourne Institute indicated that indirect tax reform could lift GDP by 3.8 per cent and create 50,000 jobs. Access Economics said that the tax package would lift GDP by 2.5 per cent and create 190,000 new jobs.

So what do the opposition do? They go out and get Professor Peter Dixon from Monash University, who is the one person they could get to say something negative about it. Professor Dixon's report called The government's tax package: further analysis based on the Monash model, on which the member for Wills laboured heavily during his presentation here today, shows that employment will be stimulated in the short run by 30,000 jobs. If you have 71,000 young unemployed peopleâ€”which the member for Capricornia seems so concerned aboutâ€”wouldn't you think that 30,000 new jobs would be a good start?

The point being made by members oppositeâ€”the best they can argueâ€”is that they are opposing a policy which will create 30,000 jobs almost immediately. We should not be too surprised that they oppose job creation of that order, because two weeks ago they voted against the retention of youth wagesâ€”and that, as I said earlier, could have affected some 71,000 young people around this country.

But let us return to Professor Dixon, who said that the short-term effects of the tax package would create 30,000 jobs. The Labor senators said at the inquiry, `Well, we don't like that. Let's make some other assumptions.' They said as members of the Senate committee, `Why don't we assume that there is a wage break-out and that, despite the fact that everybody gets a personal income tax cut and higher take-home pay, the first thing they will do is go out and ask for higher wages?'

Do you seriously think that a young married man, with two children and earning $25,000 a year, who will be $22 per week better offâ€”even after the 1.9 per cent impact of the GSTâ€”will race to his union and say, `I want more'? Of course not. Do you seriously think that an employee in a similar family situation, on annualised average weekly earnings of $38,000, who will be $58 per week better off, will go to his union or his professional association and say, `I want more'? Do you think that a skilled tradesman on $50,000 a year, who will be over $50 per week better off, will be greedy enough to turn around and ask for more?

Do you seriously tell us that the unions that you on the Labor side of this parliament representâ€”the unions that many of you came fromâ€”are so greedy, irresponsible and profligate that their members, having received pay rises of that order, will go out and push for more? Of course you do not believe it, but that is the only way that you could make the Dixon statement stack up: if they went out and asked for more, perhaps there would not be the 30,000 new jobsâ€”despite the fact that everybody one else like Econtech, Access Economics and all the other economists around Australia are saying that the number of jobs available will increase.

We learned, under Labor, just how wage break-outs cost jobs. We also learned how their bad economic management cost jobs. It was interesting to hear my colleague and neighbour the member for Capricornia talk in such passionate terms about Central Queensland. We can look at what happened when Labor were in charge of the economy. Instead of introducing the consumption tax that they so fervently embraced at the time of the 1985 tax summit, they sleazed back into this parliament in 1993â€”and the shadow minister Mr O'Connor, who is at the table, will remember this, because half his party nearly revolted over itâ€”and added one percentage point to every wholesale sales tax. The next year, in a second tranche, they did it all over againâ€”and, for good measure, put five per cent onto cars, on top of that, taking the indirect tax collection from that measure from $9 billion up to $13 billion in one fell swoop.

Let me ask the member for Capricornia what effect that had on unemployment. I will tell you what effect it had. At the high point of the introduction of those indirect taxes, we had an unemployment rate in that period fluctuating between 11.2 per cent and 10.6 per cent, the worst since the Great Depres sion. That was their economic management. As for bleating about Central Queensland in those circumstances, that was when the meatworks in Rockhampton were closing; that was when Central Queensland was in dire straits; that was when the Prime Minister of the day, Paul Keating, had to be dragged kicking and shouting to Central Queensland to look at the effects of the drought. Do not talk to me about Labor's economic management, because it did not exist.

The reform of Australia's outdated indirect tax regimes and the introduction of a goods and services tax will create jobs, because it reduces costs to businessâ€”and, more importantly, to primary producers and exportersâ€”and it makes Australia more competitive. The subject of this debate is whether the GST will create unemployment. The evidence is for the exact opposite position, and that is not just from the economists. Let us have a look at the Central Queensland coast that my neighbour talked so much about, where we have the sugarcane growing areas of Bundaberg and the coal and aluminium export industries of Gladstone.

Let us remember that 75 per cent of our primary production and our resources are exported. They require fuel, and fuel will be cheaper. There will be no GST on exports, and transport in general will be 6.7 per cent more efficient. Are you seriously going to say, against that background, that there are going to be fewer jobs? Of course not. This matter of public importance is a sham. Not only is it that, but it shows that the shadow Treasurer, like his leader, has no confidence in the matter. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â€”Prior to question time I was making some comments about the Marine Council. I want to conclude by referring to another section of parliamentary committee reports dealing with the operation of AMSA, of which the Marine Council is a part. The committee noted:

speech.para: In order to continue to improve ship safety, it is essential that pressure be maintained on participants in the industry. The committee notes that AMSA has played an important role in developing an international ship safety culture.

It is against that background, as I commented before question time, that this governmentâ€”amazinglyâ€”seeks to deregulate the industry and ignore the advice of its own committees. There has been a process of review which this government started, albeit inadequate. In August 1996 they set up the Shipping Reform Group, the SRG, but, as with too many other things this government has done, they did it in a very narrow way.

The SRG was chaired by Mr Julian Manser, the CEO of Perkins Shipping Pty Ltd. It consisted of representatives of Mobil Oil Australia, BHP, the Australian Shipowners Association, the National Bulk Commodities Group, Howard Smith Ltd and ALOR. There was no representation from the work force on that review. This has not been a process in which all stakeholders have been consulted and there has been no pretence of doing that. I might add that the SRG, on my last advice, was due to report today, on 25 March. I wonder what state that report is in. Obviously the government had no intentions of seeing it prior to legislating.

One of the most disturbing aspects of this government's approach to seafaring has been its willingness to breach International Labour Organisation conventions. We are at this time in breach of ILO convention No. 9. If this bill is passed we will be in breach of further articles of ILO convention No. 9. This matter is well understood by both sides of the parliament.

Another standing committee of the parliament on which the government has a majority is the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties. The treaties committee had a look at the situation in relation to our obligations under the ILO and said the following. Firstly, they commented on the consultation:

The process of consultation, from the formation of the SRG to the decision to denounce ILO convention 9, has been imperfect. The decision to withdraw the AMSA from the administration of the SES without first finalising the change to company employment or ensuring that other provisions were put in place means that Australia is now in breach of its international obligations.
That is the view of a joint all-party committee report to this parliament. They went on and said:
More specifically, Australia remains in breach of Article 4 of ILO convention 9, and has no way of ensuring that Article 2 is complied with.

This government, rather than adhere to its international obligations, has decided to denounce ILO convention No. 9 and in doing so has breached the procedures to be followed in denouncing the ILO convention. This government is not only incapable of honouring the convention but also incapable of withdrawing from it in accordance with the proper processes. The parliament's joint committee not only commented on but made a recommendation on this matter. It recommended that:
. . . proper consideration be given to the adoption of ILO convention No. 179 with the aim of ratification by the time ILO convention No. 9 is denounced.

There is no indication from this government that they intend to do that. Again, a committee dominated in the majority by Liberal and National Party members and senators. The fact that we are in breach of ILO conventions is a matter of some shame. Previous Liberal governments would not have countenanced a situation in which we failed to honour those minimum international standards. This government is only too willing to go down that path.

The government proposes to replace articles of agreement with a deregulated labour environment that they try and foist on other workers. I have already mentioned a quote from Justice Higgins about the nature of the relationship in one-on-one negotiations. A more contemporary authority for that comes from two prominent legal and academic people in the field of industrial relations, Mr Catanzariti and Mr Baragwanath. In their publication The Workplace Relations Act they made this observation about what happens under the government's AWA legislation when one person has to negotiate for their employment. They said this:
In a situation where the agreement is with an individual employee, that employee has virtually no bargaining power.

Those are their words, `no bargaining power'. The simple fact is that the situation in the seafaring industry is now serious where workers' basic rights are unable to be protected. Against that background this is what Minister Anderson said in his second reading speech:
Australia seafarers enjoy exceptionally good working conditions.

As far as Mr Anderson is concerned, they have got it too good. He was only echoing the views of Mr Reith, for whom these comments would have been more customary. Mr Reith went on to say that we needed these sorts of regulations in the shipping industry 100 years ago, but:
. . . this is not the case today, when Australian seafarers enjoy exceptionally good working conditions.
Let us have a look at the reality and not the political rhetoric from these ministers who are embarked upon an ideological campaign to reduce workers' rights in the seafaring industry.

The Ships of shame report, which has been widely acclaimed on both sides of this House as a seminal document in dealing with this matter, made these observations about the evidence they heard. They heard about the maltreatment of seafarers and I will quote examples that were included in their report:
denial of food and provision of inadequate food;
bashing of crew members by ships officers;
maintenance of two pay books, one for official records of International Transport Workers' Federation levels of pay, the other for the real lower level of pay;
under or non-payment of wages and overtime;
inadequate accommodation and washing facilities;
sexual molestation and rape;
depriving access to appropriate medical care; and
crew members being considered as `dispensibles'.
That is the view of a joint party committee and it is a matter of disgrace that against that background this government wants to persist with its bill. That was in 1992.

In 1998 a committee composed in the majority of Liberal and National Party members came to a similar conclusion. As I commented earlier, they found that this was one area where things needed to improve. They said this:

To a degree, violations of crew welfare are commercially driven. Costs associated with crew welfare are to some extent discretionary. Therefore, this expenditure is vulnerable to reduction when margins are slim.
That is why we need this legislative protection and exactly why we should not be supporting the bulk of this bill. That 1998 report noted these problems:
crews from non-traditional maritime nations are those which work in inadequate conditions, are poorly paid and whose living quarters are substandard.
mistreated crew members are reluctant to complain as they will be black listed. . .

many crew are forced to sign contracts which forbid them to contact the International Transport Workers' Federation, if they do they are instantly dismissed and threatened that they will never work as a seafarer again; crew members have often had to pay a fee to crewing agencies in order to secure employment. . .
