These are unfortunately all too common in the industry; an industry that this government wants Australian workers exposed to without protection or regulation.
Mr Reith would have us believe that these were problems of 100 years ago. In 1995 the second of the three reports presented to this parliament made the following observation:
. . . sub-standard ships and practices still exist; crews are still being beaten, harassed, abused and deprived of basic human rights.
That was an all-party unanimous view in 1995. In 1998, I repeat, the committee said:
In all the focus various before the committee in this inquiry, crew welfare appears to have progressed the least in 1990s, and much remains in need of improvement.

The competitive advantage of the global economy and the competitive advantage of Australian industries should not be built at the expense of Australian workers' conditions, employment and safety. That is precisely what this government would have us do. It is a position well understood in Europe and the United States, but unfortunately ignored here.

In the couple of minutes remaining to me I want to turn to specifics and the matter of forged certificates. The government wants to deregulate the circumstances in which crew are to be certified. It is an undesirable fact of life that globally in this industry forged certificates are all too common. In 1992 the Ships of shame report said:
It is undeniable that the quality of crew training is a central factor in maintaining ship safety.

Unfortunately, this bill seeks to end the certification process that currently exists under the articles of agreement. You will then have employers deciding for themselves who they will employ and on what conditions and they will satisfy themselves about the qualifications. Everyone in this House knows what will occur. Employers out there will gladly take people on forged certificates for lower rates of pay, and in the process jeopardise themselves, their fellow crew, the ship, the environment and other seafarers.
Possession of forged qualifications by some crew was noted in the 1992 report which stated:

Possession of forged qualification certificates by some crew members and the failure of others to have appropriate certificates are also a matter of concern. For example, it has been reported that in a recent crackdown by the Japanese Ministry of Transport, 25 officers on board 11 foreign vessels were found to have no proper qualification certificates.
More recently we have the comments of Captain Bolitho. He is the former chairman of the Australian Shipping Line. In an address in August last year he made the following comment:

Professor David Moresby of the Institute of Maritime Studies at the University of Plymouth, demonstrated that for $US300 it is possible to purchase a masters certificates perfect in every detail, except that name is left blank for you to fill in . . . approximately 20 per cent of the world's seafarers are now from the Philippines and . . . 90 per cent of them are sailing on worthless paper.

That is the reality of the seafaring industry. The only thing that protects Australia from that is this legislation that is now before the parliament that the government is seeking to overturn. This bill is very bad legislation, driven by ideological hatred, driven by an unfortunate political desire of this government to persecute seafarers and anyone associated with the Maritime Union. It is very bad public policy and we will be opposing a large portion of it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â€”It is my pleasure to rise today and support the government's Navigation Amendment (Employment of Seafarers) Bill 1998 . It is very interesting to follow the member for Brisbane and find out why the Labor Party are in such a time warp. They are back in the fifties and have not grasped the fact that the number of people who are joining trade unions is falling at an unprecedented rate. The reason is that the world has changed significantly and the ability of employers to deal directly with employees has changed and people are very happy to deal direct with their employees. This is what it is about. This bill is bringing the seafarers under the same act as the Workplace Relations Act. It is an act which obviously has brought significant reforms across the board in the industrial scene in Australia. To have one group of employees, the seafarers, fall outside of the provisions of the Workplace Relations Act is obviously a nonsense and anomalous in today's world.

speech.para: I would like to congratulate the government and the minister for much of the success of the reforms that have been carried out on the waterfront. The protracted dispute and difficulties that occurred at Patricks have resulted in significantly improved productivity on the wharves. Australia fell so far behind the rest of the world, places like Rotterdam and Singapore, in the loading rate per hour and the number of containers that were loaded in a day. It is this government that has had the guts to make the changes necessary to bring our economy in line with the rest of the world. This act is part of bringing us into line with provisions in other parts of the world.

There is nothing terribly draconian or anything machiavellian in this bill. It is simply allowing employers and employees to come to their agreements together. When this government brought in the single voyage permit, the changes made a significant difference to the number of cruise operators that come into Australian waters. The Minister for Sport and Tourism, who is at the table, would be aware of the significant increase we have had in cruise operations into Australian waters. You just have to check the number of cruise vessels that have come into Australian ports over the last 12 months due to the changes by this government to recognise that we are reforming the waterfront in a number of areas.

The shipping industry has been hamstrung by union dominated requirements for far too long. The main aim of this bill is to remove employment related provisions in the act which are inconsistent with the Workplace Relations Act and the concept of company employment. Time has meant that provisions of this act are no longer required. For too long the waterfront and all of its aspects have been a closed shop. The whole shift to company employment means that many provisions in the 1913 act are no longer required. It tells you something when the members of the Labor Party are willing to support provisions in a 1913 act. Australia has moved significantly since that time, and it is appropriate that we should review legislation such as this.

Clearly, conditions of employment for seafarers should be no different from other industry groups. There are clearly questions to be determined by employers and employees. This is not a special case, not a different industry. The Workplace Relations Act provides the legislative framework in which the needs of individual companies can be obtained through the Workplace Relations Act 1996. Having that framework in place means that this particular legislation becomes redundant.

The prime purpose of the act is to remove the employment provisions from the Navigation Act 1912 that are inconsistent with the concept of company employment and with the aims of the Workplace Relations Act 1996. A Shipping Reform Group, appointed by the former Minister for Transport and Regional Development, John Sharp, and chaired by Julian Manser, said that a system of company employment should be established and the current seafarers engagement system terminated. The arrangement under the Navigation Act requires that all seafarers enter into an agreement with the master of the vessel on which they sail. The agreement which is prepared on a prescribed form covers such matters as the period of employment, wages, arrangements for allocation of wages and arrangements for discharge of a seafarer.

Officers working on Australian ships are not employed under articles of agreement. Instead they have individual contracts with the owner of the vessel. All seafarers employed on Australian built ships operating on the Australian coast or on ships imported into Australia are required to be Australian residents or to have temporary visas. Visas may be issued up to a period of four years, subject to labour market tests under the Migration Act 1958. The Migration Act precludes foreign crew members from working coastal waters without such visas.

The other provision is that Australian seafarers have been employed under an employment system known as the seafarers engagement system or `the roster'. This was criticised by the Shipping Reform Group, which stated that the roster system for ratings, which has not allowed the development of company employment, has a number of significant problems including lack of employment continuity and the resulting high cost of training, the inability to transfer personnel within a company's operational structure, inadequate selection arrangements and barriers to promotion, and a significant cost of the operation of the engagement system. Basically what we are talking about is bringing the whole process into 2000 style human relations management. What you want is a union controlled, union dominated, totally rigid system without the flexibility for promotion for people who show significant ability and the skills training that is necessary.
Mr Hollis interjectingâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”I am sure the honourable member opposite can boast about what he is. I am sure your good colleagues from the trade union movement would support you. Some 52 per cent of the frontbench opposite came from a trade union background of work for the ACTU or were union officials. That is all right. You can get your firing orders from the unions, but what the people in broader Australia are concerned about is how efficient our waterfronts and shipping industries are. You do not have to be a rocket scientist or even a member of the Labor Party to know that our waterfront has been a disgrace for many years. In those long, sad, black years when Labor was in power, there was no reform of the waterfront, just more entrenchment of the rigidity that existedâ€”
â€”Of course there was, and you know it.

â€”There were lots of claims and lots of payouts, and nothing happened. Many millions of dollars were spent, but there was no basic change in the number of people on the waterfront or in how long it took to load a container at Sydney ports. The same applies to the shipping industry within Australia. It is full of rigidity, full of inefficiencies and full of union domination by their old mates and the lists that they brought in. It was like, `Okay, Joe, it's your turn to get on the list, and we'll look after your cousin as well.' It was not about the modern human relations plan of looking after the individual and for them to negotiate directly with their employer as to the conditions in which they will operate. I am very proud that this government has brought in this type of enlightened legislation. It reflects modern human management of resources.

speech.para: The Shipping Reform Group recommended the termination of the seafarers engagement system and predicted that the positive outcomes from introducing company employment would include improved employer-employee relations, the forging of an enterprise culture and outcomes, a more efficient introduction of quality management systems, more effective manpower planning, and the development of additional skills and competencies specific to the needs of enterprise and individuals. These recommendations are about improving the relationship between employers and employees. They are not about worsening the situation.

They are about the forging of an enterprise culture relating to productivity and efficiency and the economic gains of doing so. They are about quality management systems and effective manpower planning in order to work out the progression of seafarers within the area of operation so they can look forward to progression according to their merits and their performance. That is the norm these days in the 1990s culture in Australia. Why should the waterfront and the seafarers be any different?

One of the main features of the act will be to abolish the Marine Council and its functions. The Marine Council was established under section 424 of the Navigation Act 1912. Its members consist of equal numbers of representatives of shipowners and seafarers together with an employee of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. The minister appoints the members and the chairperson. Its principal role is to assess the suitability of people for employment at sea.

Why on earth would you have a board set up by legislation to establish the suitability? Why is this any different from somebody who goes down to General Motors and wants a job working on the Holden production plant? There is a personnel and human resources division. They assess the individual according to their qualifications and their suitability for the job. Why do you need a board to determine it? We know why it was established: so the unions could look after their mates.

This is not a mates bill, even though mates is very much featured in our preamble, and rightly so. This is about looking after the welfare of seafarers. Those on the other side claim that they are looking after the welfare of the average worker. I can tell you this: this is liberating the seafarers to join modern Australia and their ability to be promoted according to their skills and not tied up with the rigidity we have seen in the past.

This bill plans to do away with the articles of agreement and replace them with company contracts between the employer and either individual seafarers or the crew of the vessel as a whole. What could be fairer than that? It is an agreement between the two. There has to be two sides to make the agreement. If one side does not agree, then it is not valid. It requires the agreement of the seafarers. Under company employment, the terms and conditions to apply to seafarers will be matters for negotiation between the seafarers and their employers. The employer may be the owner of the vessel or a company specialised in providing crew for ships. Such issues are matters for employers and seafarers to negotiate to allow crew to be used to clean ships' holds and move cargo in port.

In his second reading speech the minister said how significant it would be for the question of what limits are to be placed on the work to be carried out by the ship's crew to be determined by negotiation between the employer and the employee. In another speech Mr Reith talked about the need to have an unfettered employer dealing directly with new entrants into the area. He said that it was the unfettered employer's right to recruit from any source and it was the company's responsibility for new entrant recruitment and training, subject to meeting any minimum mandatory industry standards. It is right that we should look at the minimum industry standards so they are appropriate and safety concerns are taken into consideration. If you have the minimum requirement necessary for the job and you meet the safety standards, I cannot understand what the Labor Party's opposition would be, except, of course, to look after their mates in the union movement.

The concerns expressed by the Maritime Union of Australia to the bill relate to the fact that the changes would allow manning agents to supply crew for Australian vessels, that the ship's crew, including foreign crew engaged in overseas voyage, would be able to load and unload cargo in Australian ports, and would allow crew to clean the ship's ballast while in Australian ports. They also claim that the move would allow manning agents, including foreign manning agents, to provide seafarers for Australian vessels. This is all quite erroneous. The proposed measures will not affect the qualifications, competency and welfare of Australian seafarers. It will continue to be the responsibility of employers to ensure that their ships are crewed by properly qualified seafarers.

talk.start.para: â€”As they have in the past? Have a look at the record.

â€”Your government was in power for 13 years. If you had any problem in terms of their record, then why didn't you do something about it? What we have is those people who are now involved in the shipping industry saying that this is the process of reform. Section 16 of the Navigation Act says that unqualified persons performing duties of master, officer or seaman is an offence. Obviously, these concerns are false concerns and are totally erroneous.

speech.para: The Australian Maritime Safety Authority would still have the right to inspect evidence of qualifications. They can do so at any time. The member for Brisbane said that false qualifications were in existence. That is not taken away. The Australian Maritime Safety Authority still has the ability to inspect the qualifications and make sure that they are legitimate. The Navigation Act makes sure that the safety provisions are there.

So on what basis do we have objections? Are there objections to the minimum wage levels? Are they going to be eroded? No. Are we going to have an erosion of safety requirements? Absolutely not. Will we have a total absence of qualifications required because of changes to the act? Absolutely not. What we have is a sensible piece of legislation that brings the seafarers into line with the Workplace Relations Act. It is simply appropriate that they be considered as another part of the Australian industry so that we see the efficiencies and the reforms that will come as a result of this government's changes to bring this industry into line with those changes and to allow for a more effective and productive waterfront and shipping industry. I commend the minister for this piece of legislation. I am sure that, as a result of the changes proposed in this legislation, we will see a more significant and efficient shipping industry in Australia.

talk.start.para: â€”I am pleased to speak to the Navigation Amendment (Employment of Seafarers) Bill 1998 . I support the amendments foreshadowed by the shadow minister. I am sorry that the member for Cook is leaving the chamber because I intend to respond to some of his points. If the amendments are not accepted, the opposition will be opposing this bill. The member for Cook, who is now leaving the chamber, spoke about a time warp. If he wants to talk about a time warp, he ought to read the report that was brought down by a committee on which the honourable member for Corangamite and I served and which was chaired by the honourable member for Hinkler. The member for Cook ought to read that report, because it is obvious from what he said today that the nearest he has been to the waterfront was when he put his well heeled shoe onto the luxury cruiser from some jetty at Dolls Point on the Cronulla peninsula. That is the closest he has ever been to the waterfront, and he comes in here and tries to pontificate, wallowing in his ignorance.

speech.para: I extend an offer to the member for Cook, whose electorate is just to the north of mine. By agreement, in Port Kembla every time a ship comes in there and the unions ban it, they contact me. I go down and report it, and we videotape it because we are sick and tired of the crowd over there making false allegations. Next time a ship comes in, I am prepared to contact the member for Cook and in a totally bipartisan way have him come down there and inspect that ship with me. He can talk to the crew, and if they will let us we will have a look at the ship. He has come in here and made a disgraceful speech today. The member for Corangamite must have been embarrassed. Any members of the Standing Committee on Communications, Transport and Microeconomic Reform who were listening who have worked so hard on these reports must have cringed with embarrassment.

The member for Cook asked me what I had been doing during 13 years about ship safety and ship conditions. I happen to have worked on three major reports, like the honourable member for Corangamite. I have taken my study leave to talk to shipping companies and unions throughout the world. We brought down the report Ships of shame, which is recognised throughout the world. It has had major newspaper and magazine articles written about it. There have been television programs made on it. It is recognised as a major report on shipping and shipping safety and conditions on ships throughout the world. The report is known throughout the world. While the member for Cook was waltzing around to the fleshpots of the world trying to win the Sydney Olympics, that was what the member for Corangamite and I and other people were doing out of concern for the conditions of the seafarers of the world.

The member for Cook spoke about single voyage permits. He ought to learn what a single voyage permit is and have a look at some of those ships that are travelling on single voyage permits. Of course they have increased because of the laxness of this government. They are supposed to meet certain conditions before they are issued with a single voyage permit. They do not meet those conditions. Single voyage permits are increasing and they will continue to increase. They will increase even more under legislation such as this.

This bill seeks to amend or repeal some 50 sections and other items of the Navigation Act 1912. But it is significant for its deregulation of the seafarers employment. Let us get one thing clear: on this side we have never opposed reform of the shipping movement. Have a look at our record. Have a look at the number of crews on ships when we came in and when we went out. We have never been opposed to the regulation or the reform of shipping. What we do oppose is doing away with workers' conditions and rights. What we are opposed to is an ideological jihad put out by the minister and those opposite. This is all about the ideological madness and the ideological hatred of the trade union movement, especially the Maritime Union of Australia.

This bill aims to put into place the recommendations of the shipping reform group to abolish cabotage and establish a second register. Let me tell you about a second register. All a second register is is a tax evasion mechanism. The French have a second register, and their islands off the Antarctic are populated by nothing but penguins. Where would we put our second register? Would we put it on Herd Island or Macquarie Island or the Cashmore or Ashmore islands? That is probably where we would put it. To abolish cabotage: I wish the honourable member for Cook were in the chamber, because I respect him for the work he did in the tourist industry and as a New South Wales minister. The minister who was previously at the table, the member for Lindsay, is the Minister for Sport and Tourism.

All my colleagues on the other side have worked themselves into a huge lather at present because of the threat to have an open sky policy. They are afraid that, instead of Qantas trolley dollies coming down with a rattling drinks tray, they might be served by a trolley dolly from one of the Third World countries. So those opposite are very, very worried at the thought of our having an open sky policy. They are all running along to their ministers, saying, `Oh, you can't do that, you can't open up the Australian skies.'

These are the same people who get up in this chamber, sweating and frothing at the mouth about the seafarers, and say, `Oh, we've got to open up the Australian coastline to the seafarers of the world; we've got to let all the rust buckets and everything else in.' They believe that it is all right for the seafarers to have the Australian coastline opened up.

I say this: if it is good enough to open up the coastline to all the seafarers on all the rust buckets from all around the world, it is good enough to have the planes that are tied together with bits of string and chewing gum belonging to services that are being run by people all around the world; let us open the skies as well. But those opposite froth at the mouth at the thought of opening up the skies. And these people who froth at the mouth over open skies and run to the minister demanding that we do not have such a policy are the very same people who stand here and demand that our coastline be opened up to all the rust buckets of the world.
The bill was first introduced on 25 June 1998 but lapsed due to the calling of the election. It was reintroduced under a new minister on 9 December 1998.

I note, from the second reading speech, the former minister went into some detail about what was proposed by the bill. The impression he tried to giveâ€”in which he was supported by the member for Cookâ€”was of tidying up some historical anachronisms that are not relevant to the employment of seafarers in the present day. The member for Cook even said, `What's the difference between a seafarer and someone working on an assembly line at Geelong?' What great knowledge he exposed! At least the employee on the shop floor at Geelong can go home each night. They are not on a voyage for three months. They do not live on the job. There seems to me to be a lot of difference between someone working on an assembly line in Geelong and someone working on a ship.

Indeed, the former minister even managed to engage in that time honoured traditionâ€”for which, I must say, he is renownedâ€”of a bit of old fashioned union bashing. The new minister in his second reading speech of December was even less respectful in repeating that propagandaâ€”and we now know why. The Howard government has a record of attacking and undermining legislative protection in the field of industrial relations and the conditions of employment. As I said beforeâ€”and I do not retract itâ€”this is an industrial jihad those opposite are engaged on. Minister Reith in his second reading speech stated:
. . . the Workplace Relations Act provides flexibility for employment arrangements to be determined at the enterprise level in a manner that suits the business of the individual employer.
The emphasis is on the last few words. By now, every working Australian would have heard the following remarks which were made by Minister Reith at a Perth business luncheon last year:
Never forget the history of politics and never forget which side we're on. We're on the side of making profits. We're on the side of people owning private capital.

`Making profit' means that often seafarers from Third World countries go to the bottom of the sea because of the condition of their ships and the conditions under which they work. It does not matter whether people die, as long as the capitalist side can make a few extra bucks.
The Australian Financial Review in May 1997 also attributes a classic quote to the minister. It is:
People have got to stand up to the unions and we will support them. All you have to do is pick up the phone and we will support you.

And you might as well say `with balaclavaed thugs accompanied by savage mad dogs'. All of this is from a minister who at every available opportunity steps up to the mat, trying desperately to portray this side of the House as promoters of class warfare.

The effect of this bill before us is yet another element in the ideologically driven policies of this government. It continues to knock the industrial relations pendulum all the way to the extreme right. With the minister being so interested in the history of politics, as he appears to claim, he should also remember that, for every reaction, there is also an equal and opposite reaction. While this government swings to the extreme right, the opposition will be pulling the pendulum back to the centre, not only in industrial relations but also in other areas of policy. That is the history of politics and the record of enforcing a class struggle.

The Bills Digest for this bill is an interesting read. I must say that the digest has always provided, irrespective of the government of the day, quite a broad and impartial assessment of any bill's provisions. This digest, however, admittedly quoting from a speech Minister Reith gave to the Australian Shipping Chamber on 6 November 1997, has peppered throughout it the phrase `unfettered employer right'.

Who can be surprised by the recommendations of the Shipping Reform Group report? The group's purpose was clear, clinical and entirely political; it was designed to swing that pendulum I mentioned earlier to the rightâ€”to the extreme right. The group had its brief to present the case for winding back and terminating cabotage. It was about mounting a case for the establishment of a second register. I have told you about the establishment of a second register. And cabotage: if we do away with cabotage, we will be the only country in the world to do so.

One only need examine who made up the group to see just how these predictable recommendations were made. Chaired by Mr Julian Manser of Perkins Shipping and accompanied by representatives from Mobil Oil Australia, the Australian Ship Owners Association, National Bulk Commodities Group and Howard Smith Ltd. Only employer groups were represented. Where was the representation from the seafarers and other ship crews? Where was the representation from the Maritime Union of Australia or, indeed, the ACTU?

The Shipping Reform Group is a bosses' outfit, recommending a bosses' agenda for shipping to a bosses' government. One can only ask why the government did not grace the group with the presence of the Chairman of Patrick Stevedores, Chris Corrigan? But of course, he was preoccupied at the time with implementing another Howard government policy inspiration: to sack his entire work force in the middle of the night, unleash the dogs and let the balaclavaed thugs loose. He has definitely picked up the telephone!

The employment of seafarers should continue to be subject to legislative prescription, not turned over to the vagaries of the Workplace Relations Act. We on this side do not have any difficulty amending or removing historic anachronisms from the Navigation Act 1912, but not all of its sections need to be treated this way. We on this side will stand on our record of reforms to the shipping industry that we brought in during the 13 years we were in government. We are talking about the employment conditions of an entirely different group of workers, not the people on the shop floor at Geelong.

Seafarers, like coalminers, all work in a different and tough environment with a savage and brutal history and culture. Conditions of employment, indeed prescriptive legislative provisions, are recognition of that environment, culture and history. In no other industry do a group of workers disappear at sea for three months at a time. They certainly do not do that in Geelong. In no other industry do a group of workers have their working environment also double up as their accommodation and their recreation. It is absolute rubbish to even try to compare the shipping industry and the conditions of employment of seafarers with any other industry. And that is exactly what this bill is trying to do. Seafarers are subject to exploitation. Living conditions on many vessels are deficient, particularly on flag of convenience registered vessels, with too many owners and operators in the chase for a quick buck who turn a blind eye to aspects of safety.

Ever since I have been elected to serve in this place, I have had a distinct interest in shipping, representing as I do the port of Kembla. With the member for Corangamite, I have attended countless public and private hearings of the House of Representatives standing committee in its inquiry Ships of shame. All members of that committee, regardless of what side of the House they came from and their ideological bent on industrial relations, were shocked by the conditions on those ships and the working conditions that people had to put up with. That is why I keep referring back to Ship safe, a report brought down here by a committee chaired by the honourable member for Hinkler. That report dealt with conditions on ships.

The member for Cook spoke garbageâ€”as though everything there was wonderful. I am disappointed and a bit embarrassed that the member for Hinkler is not here, but I know the member for Corangamite will adequately put the case. I hope that especially the members who served on these committee inquiries dealing with ship safety have not been gagged and refused permission to speak by the minister on that side. There are only two members from the government side who will be speaking. Many members there have served on these committees and have put their names to this report which highlights conditions. I know the parliamentary secretary has read the report, but she should refresh her memory by just flicking through it to see how embarrassed we should be by the comments of the honourable member for Cook.

I have seen many rust buckets. I have talked to seafarers from the Third Worldâ€”in fact, I have spoken to them in the electorate of the member for Hinkler and, indeed, in my own electorate. I am on the board of the Mission to Seamen where we see seafarers coming along almost nightly. Many of them tell us about the food, that they are half starved and that they are abused. I have heard about the non-payment of wages; the disgusting living and working conditions; the torture and physical, mental and sexual abuse; and also, in many cases, the final tragedyâ€”death. There are many, many seafarers from Third World countries who leave the ports of Kembla, Sydney or Melbourne to go to Brisbane, but if they are regarded as a troublemaker they never see the port of Brisbaneâ€”they disappear overboard off the coast of New South Wales and no-one mentions it.

We have taken evidence under oath about the denial of food, the provision of inadequate food, the bashing of crew members by ships' officers, the maintenance of two sets of pay books which the member for Brisbane men tioned, underpayment of wages and overtime, inadequate accommodation and washing facilities, access to proper medical care and all sorts of deprivation. I am passionate about the defence and protection of seafarers all over the world, particularly our own Australians. This bill threatens Australian seafarers, it threatens their livelihood, and it goes further than that. It also threatens the coastline of Australia because, if you have a poorly trained, half-starved crew, they cannot properly carry out their duties. So our coastline is at risk. Rather than seeking to improve the conditions for all seafarers, it lowers our own standards.

The bill also threatens our vast coastline by permitting the entry of rust buckets and allowing crews to clean vessel ballast while in port. The bill also threatens to make Third World labour even more attractive to unscrupulous shipowners and operators. The government is, quite frankly, renewing an interest in a practice so morally and legally indicted throughout the modern world, and that is slavery.

The practice of crimping, the government says, was only prevalent in the days of sailing ships. It ignores the factâ€”and, I might add, the significant evidenceâ€”that this abuse is still very active in modern shipping, just as it was a century ago. Yet, just to show how imaginative Australia is, this government is taking us down the road of denouncing ILO convention No. 9, Placing of Seamen 1920. Australia has enjoyed a cooperative relationship with the International Labour Organisation but, like most areas, our participation has been kneecapped by the Liberal government.

The honourable member for Brisbane referred to the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties of this parliament and its criticism of the government over ILO conventions. We on this side support reform of the shipping industry. We will not support the measures in this bill. If the amendments foreshadowed by the shadow minister are not accepted, we will be voting against this disastrous legislation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â€”I acknowledge the great depth of knowledge that the member for Throsby has on this issue. Whilst I might strongly disagree with most of what he has to say, I do acknowledge his lifetime interest in maritime matters, his understanding of the human side of that particular industry and, I might say, his strong support of the MUA and associated personnel on the waterfront. So members of this House would be aware of where he is coming from.

speech.para: I make the fundamental proposition that we are talking about Australian shipping in the Navigation Amendment (Employment of Seafarers) Bill 1998 and the crews on Australian shipping. Whilst the member for Throsby and the shadow minister have spent considerable time talking about the Ships of shame, the very important landmark report, I do draw to the attention of other members that it fundamentally dealt with ships that travelled on the international shipping lanes and the problems that this government, the former government and the Australian authorities have in maintaining reasonable standards on those ships. That is the fundamental difference that I would have with the member for Throsby.

Most of the ships that travel on the Australian runs that come under these new sets of conditions are not related to those more questionable conditions on the international trade routes. I do accept the comments that the member for Throsby has raised. He and I conscientiously sat on the committee for many months and weeks listening to some quite horrific evidence from seafarers and shipowners and evidence of those poor souls who are no longer with us who have gone to the bottom in some of the ore ships that silently disappeared into the Indian Ocean.

It is important to note the key arguments about those shipsâ€”the flags of convenience shipsâ€”that the member for Throsby referred to in the large part of his speech and that the shadow minister referred to. The skills of those crews have been accumulatedâ€”that is, crews from various parts of the world did not have the use of a common language, be it English, Portuguese or Norwegian. The age of the ship was a very fundamental factor. It was interesting evidence that ships between the age of 17 and 25 years had a higher incidence of sinking.

The insurance arrangements of these international shipping lines was a matter of contention for those insurance companies that were providing insurance for these ships in a very questionable state. As the honourable member opposite and I would agree, quite often these problems were at the feet of the insurance agencies who were prepared to `make a fast buck', to use his words, to insure ships which obviously should not have been involved in the movement of iron ore and other bulk products.

I will refute some of the remarks of the shadow minister, who really described some of the industrial relations arguments and really did not know a lot about shipping. I am not blaming him for that because he comes from the teachers union and he has not had the experience of the member for Throsby and me of being hands-on in the shipping industry. He referred to Justice Higgins of 1907. It is his point of view that we ought to retain those outdated approaches.

In terms of the ILO convention or other treaties signed by Australiaâ€”and the honourable member for Throsby remarked about the ILOâ€”I will say that I have a personal distaste that unelected members comprising the United Nations treaties are able to bring about terms and conditions on a range of subject matters which have been before the House on other occasionsâ€”for instance, ILO convention No. 22 dates back to 1926. The member opposite is saying that that is okay. I am suggesting that we should make some changes.

As I understand it, the basic requirement of ILO convention No. 22 is that employment conditions on a ship covered by an agreement be preserved, with the details left to be negotiated by the employers and the seafarers concerned. What would be wrong with that? The management of these ships would be able to negotiate a set of terms and conditions compatible to the operation. So fundamentally I say to members of the House that we are talking about a change to an act that was initially set up in 1912, before the First World War, and now we are suggesting in 1999 that we make a fundamental change to the way in which we handle the Australian shipping operation.

As the member opposite would be aware, Australia has a small trading fleetâ€”three per cent by volume and five per cent by value of world trade. It is a fleet consisting of 42 coastal and 20 overseas vessels. That is not big, but it does undertake an important transport task. There has been a decline in the transport market share since the 1970s based on tonnes-kilometres in this big island nation of oursâ€”some 52 per cent was carried by sea in 1970 and 31 per cent in 1993.

We need to make the Australian shipping industry more competitive and get it into the 1990s. It is imperative that we look at the labour costs involved in the operation of the ships and we look at the crew numbers that have gradually been reduced. I concede the point to the honourable member for Throsby that there has been reasonable cooperation between the maritime unions in reducing the crewing numbers on the ships over time and improving their skill standards. In 1984, there was an average of 30 per ship and in 1992 there were 21, and the quality of those crews have improved.

There were some slight changes in this whole areaâ€”better quality ships and improved crewingâ€”but the attitudes remained the same. They were protected by this act, protected by these sets of terms and conditions, which really do not stand up in the modern day. So, in 1993, the former government, to give them some credit, provided $25 million for voluntary redundancy programs. As I understand it, that did work out where some of the personnel on the maritime runs were able to leave the industry with some dignity. With these enterprise agreements that came in in 1994 under the maritime industry restructuring agreement, there was a movement in the right direction. Even the Labor government understood that you needed to have an enterprise agreement and get away from these very restrictive operations, and I will talk more about that in a minute.

I will illustrate the importance of the cargo industry in Australia: carrying general cargo across Bass Strait; carrying dry bulk servicesâ€”more than 30 billion tonnesâ€”around the Australian coastline; transporting crude oil to the various refineries, in particular to the refinery in Geelong in my home electorate; moving iron ore from Port Hedland to Port Kembla, close to the member for Throsby's electorate; and moving coal from New South Wales to Queensland and to Japan. Of course, the international ANL shipping line, which has now been sold, was involved in some of those activities.

The aim of this legislation which we are debating before the House is to bring the Navigation Act into line with the Workplace Relations Act. I have had, personally, a long interest in these matters, in trying to bring about a change from a highly regulated workplace set of arrangements under the Industrial Relations Commission to a more flexible set of arrangements. Even the member opposite could go along with that. We have more flexible arrangements for modern ships where a smaller numbers of crews are better trained, where they can reach an agreement with the senior personnelâ€”the captains and the managementâ€”and not go back to rules and regulations that are based in 1912. How would the member opposite defend that position, on any ground?

The reality is that we are moving a set of circumstances which the Labor Party fundamentally agreed with when they were in government. They moved towards enterprise agreements, but it was the friends and associates of the member for Throsby who made sure that that did not actually happen. They did not reach enterprise agreements because his union friends and colleagues and his good friend on the waterfront John Coombs made sure that that old set of arrangements were kept in place come hell or high water.

This legislation changes the act of 1912. I just emphasise the point, comrade from Throsby, that it was from 1912; that is how far back we go. This will change the period of employment, the allocation of wages and the discharge of seafarers. We are now moving to industry employment. There was traditionally no loyalty to the shipowner because it was a changing situation. We now have a situation where seafarers, because there are fewer of them, wish to stick with the particular shipping lines they are operating with. They hope to get a better set of terms and conditions by negotiation rather than by staying in the casual set-up that used to be the caseâ€”and which I concede is the case in other parts of the world.

We are moving to enterprise agreements. That is the norm in the Australian workplace. More and more, people are starting to understand the significance of a particular set of crew working under a particular set of management. So we will have an enterprise culture and we will have improvement in the quality of management. I concede that the quality of the management in some of these shipping lines, as the honourable member of Throsby has mentioned, was very questionable, especially on some of the international lines under flags of convenience where crew members had very little training and where direction from senior personnel was less than ordinary. Under these arrangements skills can be developed and employees will become better sailors and better able to employ their skills for one employer.

The bill will abolish the Maritime Council. This is an interesting set of circumstances. The Maritime Council, as I understand it, was formed under section 424(2) of the Navigation Act 1912. It had members representing shipowners, members representing seafarers and a representative of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. The minister appointed them. They had a little get-together and worked out who could work on which ship. You had a classic situation of a closed shop. So, unless you had a brother, a cousin or a father in the industry, you could not get a job at sea because they were very tightly held, as they were on the waterfront.

I think the honourable member opposite would be happy to concede that the waterfront was an absolutely closed shop. There is no doubt that I would not get a job there. But I am sure that the member for Throsby would because he had a lot of friends there. It is the same situation for the seafarers in Australia. Those jobs were tightly held by those peopleâ€”so much so that you were not able to recruit anyone from outside the little family. You had to recruit from a particular line-up of personnel. This legislation will make a dramatic change in the ability of the employers, those shipowners, to recruit from employment agencies those seafarers who have got some experience, who have got good attitudes and who wish to make a lifetime job of it.

We will make a change to the attitude that is in the mining industry and in the waterfront industry that those who are last on are first off. That has been the attitude. If you got on the register and you got a job and then after a while you were put off, if you were last on you would be first off. The member for Throsby fully understands that, and he cannot really refute the fact that that is the situation.

There was a situation where the seafarers on Australian built ships on the Australian coast had to be Australian residentsâ€”again, a closed shop arrangement. They did not let anyone come in, so they had to have a temporary visa. Now at least there will be some capacity to employ skilled seafarers under the auspices of the Ships of shame who have been well trained in the Philippines and who we have made sure have bona fide certificates of competency. Why shouldn't the shipping industry of Australia enjoy the benefit of these well trained international personnel who have tickets of competency from the Philippines training school and other reputable areas who could come and enjoy the better conditions here on the Australian coastline?

I notice that section 45 of the Navigation Act places restrictions on the crew handling of cargo and ballast when a ship is in the Australian port. This was linked to the waterside workers' ancient demand that only they could drive the ships' winches. What a remarkable position! The ship pulls up on the Australian waterfront, and here is this different set of conditions whereby only the waterside workers can drive the ship's cranes.

How can the honourable member opposite or the shadow minister argue that that is a reasonable set of arrangements? I understand that they were pushed into that little lurk back in 1911. `We have got jobs for the boys, and we will keep this in 1999.' How can you defend that situation? There was an argument that it defended safety. As your good friend John Coombs argued on the waterfront we had to have everyone on every job for safety reasonsâ€”and we know the net result of that. There was a very poor safety record because of some attitudinal problems, overmanning and the way in which there was such a closed shop on the waterfront, which is no longer the case.

The outcome of these very important changes is that the ships on the Australian coastline will be using those sailors who have had a change of attitude; who will be well trained; who will be down to 19, 20, 21 in a crew; who will have a continuity of employment; who will be supervised by AMSA. AMSA will not only be observing the quality of the ships, as the honourable member would be aware, on the Australian run but observing and reporting on the quality and the defects of the international shipping that comes to Australia.

The bill is a major breakthrough and reflects the way in which Australian industrial conditions have changed. There has been a breaking down of the monopoly position on the waterfront of the Maritime Union and within the shipping industry. I concede the point that there has been an improvement, and this will allow a further improvement to bring about much better conditions for those hardworking maritime personnel whom I concede spend months away from their home base and whose conditions historically have not been as good as they should have been. But they do enjoy high rates of pay and long periods of holiday for which they receive full pay and conditions.

This bill before the House brings into line the maritime industry for seafarers as the other industrial relations changes brought in by the minister have brought about such a dramatic change on the Australian waterfront. We will have people on both sides of the industry actually working for a full day's pay for a full day's workâ€”a most unusual set of circumstances on the Australian waterfront. We see quite dramatic changes having taken place there. We see a halving of the personnel so that even the member for Throsby can understand that there must have been a rorting of the system and there must have been an overmanning on the waterfront by any meas ure, by any judgment, by any calculation of the container lifts per hour.

I commend the bill in every aspect. It brings about a change that is compatible to the 1990s and gets away from 1912. It is in line with the government's changes to industrial relations. It will bring about a better set of conditions for the seafarers. It will bring about a more profitable domestic shipping industry and it will ensure that the quality of the ships is maintained and improved. I reject most of the suggestions put forward by those oppositeâ€”especially the shadow minister, who did not have a great understanding of the issues at handâ€”and I totally reject the assertion that the speakers on this side are from the dry side of the argument, as he put it. We come with a deep understanding of the arguments and a good feel for the conditions that some of those seafarers have enjoyed and not enjoyed over the years.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Stone) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration forthwith.
(1) Schedule 1, item 1, page 3 (lines 5 and 6), omit the item.
(2) Schedule 1, item 17, page 7 (lines 6 and 7), omit the item.
(3) Schedule 1, item 18, page 7 (lines 8 and 9), omit the item, substitute:
18 Subsection 192(5) (definition of designated period )
Repeal the definition, substitute:
designated period , in relation to a core regulated airport, means:
(a) the 12-month period beginning at whichever of the following times is applicable:

(i) if, at any time, an airport lease for the airport was granted under section 21 of the Airports (Transitional) Act 1996 to a companyâ€”the sale time for that company (within the meaning of that Act);
(ii) if, at any time, an airport lease for the airport was granted under section 22 of the Airports (Transitional) Act 1996 â€”the time of the grant of that lease; or
(b) if the ACCC, by written determination, specifies a longer period in respect of the airportâ€”that longer period.
Add:

(6) The period specified in respect of an airport in a determination under paragraph (b) of the definition of designated period in subsection (5) must not be longer than the 24-month period beginning at whichever of the following times is applicable:

(a) if, at any time, an airport lease for the airport was granted under section 21 of the Airports (Transitional) Act 1996 to a companyâ€”the sale time for that company (within the meaning of that Act);
(b) if, at any time, an airport lease for the airport was granted under section 22 of the Airports (Transitional) Act 1996 â€”the time of the grant of that lease.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: That the amendments be agreed to.

Under the Airports Act, the airport lessees had 12 months to negotiate access undertakings with airport users. The Airports Amendment Bill proposed to extend this time period to two years. Our experience is that airport lessees have difficulty meeting the ACCC's requirements within the original deadline. The Senate has amended the bill and removed the automatic 12-month extension but replaced it with a system so that the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission can grant an extension to an airport at its discretion. The government supports these amendments.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank the government for accepting these amendments because they do strike a better balance between the rights of the airport owners and the airport users. When I made my comments on the Airports Amendment Bill 1999 in this place recently, I did say that I found the idea of blanket extensions for all airportsâ€”no matter whatâ€”a difficult one. These amendments actually mean that we can now look at it on a case by case basis as airport owners' needs arise. It is still 12 months, but where owners have a problem they can apply to the ACCC, and I think that is a much better system than saying everybody can have an extra 12 months. I thank the minister for meeting our objection to blanket extensions and for agreeing to these amendments in a constructive and cooperative way.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: â€”On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the 62nd general report of the committee.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: â€”by leaveâ€”The report which I have tabled is the committee's 62nd general report covering the period 1 January to 31 December 1998. This report covers the work of the 32nd committee from 1 January to 31 August 1998 when the House of Representatives was dissolved and parliament was prorogued and the 33rd committee from 10 December when it met for the first and only time for the balance of the calendar year. As such, the report deals with committee operations under the chairmanship of the member for O'Connor, Mr Tuckey, ably supported by the vice-chairman, the honourable member for Throsby, Mr Hollis.

speech.para: The 32nd committee tabled five reports during 1998. The total estimated cost of projects examined by the committee was $560.67 million. The election period limited the committee's operation during the year. The five reports presented is the same number of reports presented during 1996. This relatively small number does not reflect the complexity of two references which consumed considerable time. These were the proposed new facilities for the National Museum of Australia and the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies, and the proposed East Coast Armament Complex, Point Wilson, Victoria.

It is rare for the committee's inquiries to extend beyond one or two days of public hearings. One reason for this has been the thoroughness of submissions and oral evidence presented by proponent departments in support of proposed works. Another reason is the general support of proposed works by state and local government and interested organisations and individuals. It is when these factors are lacking that the committee's inquiries may be lengthy and protracted.

The committee's inquiry into the Museum of Australia extended from December 1997 to mid-April 1998, during which four public hearings were held. Although recommending that the project proceed, in view of a number of uncertainties, principally about the cost of work and the suitability of project delivery mechanisms to be adopted, the committee requested to be provided with six-monthly progress reports. The government agreed with this request.

The committee's inquiry into the East Coast Armament Complex was also lengthy. The project referred to the committee was estimated to cost $72.27 million and involved the construction of facilities at Point Wilson to support the ammunitioning and de-ammunitioning of RAN ships and to provide facilities for the importation of munitions for the Defence Force.

The committee's inquiry extended from mid-February to mid-June 1998 and involved public hearings and inspections at six locations spread over geographical locations from Far North Queensland to coastal Victoria. The length of the inquiry can be attributed to an erroneous perception by the Department of Defence that the scope of the committee's inquiry would not extend beyond an examination of the need for and the scope of the facility to be constructed at Point Wilson. This inquiry provides a good illustration of the committee's role in safeguarding the public interest.

The report canvasses a number of other matters raised in the committee's reports during the year, overseas works, details of medium works submitted by departments, Commonwealth fire safety policy, and amendments to the Public Works Committee Act.

As I mentioned earlier, during 1998 the parliament was well served by the committee under the chairmanship of the honourable member for O'Connor and the vice-chairmanship of the honourable member for Throsby. I believe the report demonstrates how the honourable members served the parliament through the committee with dedication and distinction and upheld the long tradition of bipartisanship which has been the hallmark of the committee's operations.

I would also like to place on record a vote of appreciation for the hard work of the other members of the committee during 1998 and, of course, the very capable secretariat that supports this work. I commend the report to the House.

debate.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: â€”In addressing the adjournment this evening, I want to refer to a major local community issue in my electorate of Batman at the moment. It relates to the decision by the Victorian government to close the Preston and Northcote Community Hospital, better known as PANCH, and to relocate what has been a wonderful community hospital to the new Northern Hospital at Epping.

speech.para: In making this decision, I also point out to the House that the state government made promises to the local community that, unfortunately to date, have not been honoured. Those promises related to the fact that, in relocating PANCH, the Victorian government would open a new integrated care centre on the site currently occupied by PANCH. The Kennett government stated that the integrated care centre was to provide a range of day surgery, renal dialysis, chemotherapy, medical procedures, outpatient clinics, diagnostics and aged care programs.

The problem is that the decision by the Victorian government to break that promise represents the loss of very important health services to the northern suburbs of Mel bourne. The community is also upset not only by the decision of the government but by the failure of the Minister for Health and the Premier to be accountable to the northern suburbs with respect to this issue and by the fact that these ministers have refused to attend two community meetings held to discuss this issue.

On that basis, the following mocking letter about the attitude of the Victorian government was read out at a major community meeting held at the Northcote town hall last week. It represents a supposed response to an invitation to the Victorian Premier, Mr Kennett, to attend this community meeting. The letter reads as follows:
When I first heard of your little rally and your fight to save PANCH I felt physically sick. You really are a disloyal whinging un-Victorian rabble.

Have any of you ever stopped to think about how I feel? No you just greedily ask for basic health services without a thought for me. You all know how much I have given to the Preston and Northcote areas during my term as your premier.
But let me outline my record for those of you with short memories.

I've removed all those annoying schools, I've locked up the toilets on stations, I've taken the conductors off your trams and the staff off your stations, I put up your water and gas rates, I sold off your council owned electricity departments, I've taken funding away from your roads and creeks and I even sacked your elected council. Yet after all this service to your community you people still have the temerity to question my decision to remove your hospital.

I am sick to the stomach at your lack of gratitude. I am also broke. I'd like to see some of your Preston pensioners get by on my wage and my super. I'll be lucky to walk away from this Premier job with $1 million in super. After years of making my mates Lloyd Williams, Kerry Packer and Ron Walker rich beyond their wildest dreams I will retire a practical pauper.
So I have thought about my plight and I've thought about your plight and I've come up with a solution.
I've decided to resign next year and restore medical facilities to PANCH that I will personally run.
The site will have full facilities, a maternity ward, a cardiac unit, and childcare services and will be known as `The Jeff Kennett Memorial PANCH Casino'.
The cardiac unit will be placed next to the pokies hall so that any heart attacks can be promptly treated and the customers can be wheeled back to the pokies machines with a minimum of fuss.
Child care will be provided in a most modern manner by a car park attendant who will monitor that all cars have the windows down to allow the children to breath.
A maternity ward will be provided adjacent to the black jack room so those mothers can gamble right through the full gestation period.
This proposal will not only provide you with medical services but it will give me the tens of millions of dollars that I deserve in my retirement.
Now please go home and don't annoy me again.
Yours sincerely,
JEFF KENNETT, Sole director of PANCH Casino and Premier of Victoria
Spring Street, Melbourne.

The letter speaks for itself. The Kennett government has taken away vital community services from the northern suburbs of Melbourne. It is yet another broken promise, similar to the broken promises of the Howard government.

Give the site back to the community. They built the hospital by raising money through raffles and cooking cakes. It is a community hospital. We are entitled to have an integrated care centre on our site, rather than Jeff Kennett's matesâ€”Walker and the rest of themâ€”yet again getting access to a major community site. Let us make sure we put community services where they are entitled to beâ€”on a community site that was built and developed by the communities of Preston and the northern suburbs of Melbourne.
Question resolved in the nagative.

subdebateinfo.title: Economics, Finance and Public Administration Committee

talk.start.para: â€”I thank the House for the facility, in the absence of this statement earlier. On Monday, 22 March 1999, the member for Cunningham raised as a matter of privilege the alleged premature publication of the contents of the report of the Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration on regional banking services. In accordance with the practice of the House in such matters, the matter was required to be considered by the committee in the first instance. Yesterday, the honourable member for Wannon, as chair of the committee, reported on the committee's consideration of the matter. I am grateful to the Deputy Speaker for drawing the matter to my attention.

speech.para: While there might be circumstances where expeditious decision may be desirable, I believe that in the normal course of events it is preferable for a motion, such as a possible reference of a matter to the Committee of Privileges, to be decided after the House has been provided with appropriate time to consider the proposed reference.

The member for Wannon informed the House yesterday that the committee had concluded that substantial interference with its work had not occurred. The member indicated that substantial potential interference with the committee system might have resulted from the disclosure. The committee was unable to ascertain the source of any disclosure. In accordance with the procedure adopted by previous Speakers, in these circumstances I am willing to allow precedence to a motion on this matter. I call the chairman of the committee, the honourable member for Wannon.

talk.start.para: â€”Thank you, Mr Speaker, for facilitating this opportunity. I present to the House a copy of the article that was in the Financial Review on Monday, 22 March 1999, and a copy of the transcript of the AM program of the same day. I move:

speech.para: That the following matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges for inquiry and report: Whether there was an unauthorised disclosure of the Regional banking services: Money too far away report of the Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

debate.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: â€”Members of the House are well aware of my strong support for the government's Tough on Drugs program and of the work that we commenced with parents and school principals during my previous term serving the electorate of Makin. Today I would like to speak briefly about another important aspect of the Tough on Drugs programâ€”treatment and rehabilitation of those who have fallen victim to the scourge of drug addiction. While I have talked on these issues before, I think my comments are worth reiterating this evening.

speech.para: Calls from some sectors of our community for heroin to be legally available to drug addicts failed to take into account the many advances that have been made in recent times in the area of treatment of drug addiction. Firstly, there are a number of drugs that are able to be used in the context of detoxification and/or maintenance. For example, heroin addicts can be stabilised for short periods of time with the use of codeine linctus taken with doloxene, until they can be detoxed in a program involving naltrexone. Some may be aware that naltrexone has been used very effectively to block the brain's receptors and eliminate the physical craving for heroin.

Another initiative that should be embraced is the development of drug courts in all of our states, so that drug addicts who have also become criminals can be given the option of entering into treatment, rehabilitation, detoxification and follow-up counselling rather than going to gaol. This could potentially have an enormous impact on breaking the cycle of addiction and crime that has held so many drug users in its grip. I sincerely hope that my parliamentary colleagues in South Australia, and particularly my colleague Martin Hamilton-Smith, chair of the select committee investigating the options available in the fight against heroin addiction, give thought to this process.

I congratulate my colleague the member for Hughes for her work in raising this issue in her home state of New South Wales. I understand that this concept is being pursued in both New South Wales and Victoria. I also commend Mr Ross Goodridge for his analysis of the research in this area which shows that the use of drug courts may be expected to result in: a cost saving in judicial timeâ€”that is, one judge does the work of seven; reoffend rates down from 85 per cent to as low as 15 per cent; cost savings per arrestee of approximately $18,000; a real improvement in crime and drugs in society; as well as a significant decrease in suicides and health costs.

With so many positive initiatives being undertaken to help people break the cycle of despair that is the hallmark of drug addiction, it is disappointing that we should have to put up with the antics of an irresponsible performer who has seen fit to encourage young people into illicit drug use. Recently my eldest son attended The Big Day Out concert which was held in Adelaide. One of the performers there was a person by the name of Marilyn Manson. Mr Manson is one of a long line of rock stars who set out deliberately to shock and offend. Mr Manson, while portrayed as shocking and outrageous, is merely disgusting and pathetic.

If you consider that in our day we experienced the performances of Alice Cooper, David Bowie, Lou Reed and Kiss, then Manson is downright boring and, according to many of our young people, a big joke. His act included spitting into the crowd and, more alarmingly, exhorting the crowd of mostly young people to consume illicit drugs. It is bad enough that Mr Manson should choose to engage in such a low rent, disgusting activity as spitting at people, but my concern is that should he have hepatitis C or any other health problem then his sharing of bodily fluids would not just be disgusting, it would be dangerous, irresponsible and life threatening.

The question is being asked of me by some people as to why Marilyn Manson was allowed into Australia. Upon speaking to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, I was advised that as Mr Manson does not have a criminal record there was no legal reason for him to be kept out of the country by the federal government.

I raise the issue of Mr Manson as a potential role model from the music industry for our young people, and The Big Day Out concert in which he appeared, on behalf of Ms Ros Phillips of the Festival of Light, who had raised some of these issues with me as her local federal member. In relation to The Big Day Out concert, initially I did have very grave concerns for my son who was attending the concert. However, when I sat down to discuss this with my son, my concerns and fears were allayed. When I asked my son's opinion of Manson, he just laughed and said, `Not only was his music a joke, but so was he.'

However, there still remains the issue of Manson's inappropriate violent and health endangering behaviour at the concert. Let us promote real talent in Australia. We have got plenty of great local bands just waiting for their chance, and they do not spit at or violently assault their patrons. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â€”I rise this afternoon to discuss some fairly irrelevant and erroneous comments made by a Northern Territory minister in relation to the Alice Springs and Central Australian economy. And I speak of the newly appointed Minister for Central Australia, who has made comments published in the Alice Springs News dated 24 March 1999, and this morning on ABC radio in the Northern Territory. What these comments from this particular person point out is the lack of vision, wisdom, understanding and knowledge about the Central Australian economy, about its current state and about the potential impact upon it of a GST if it were ever passed through this parliament and imposed.

speech.para: You may know that the housing and construction industries and the tourism industry have been highlighted as two areas that would be negatively affected by any GST. As a result of work which has been done recently by the Alice Springs Town Councilâ€”they have produced a report presenting an economic profile of the Alice Springs communityâ€”we have seen a clear flattening of the housing industry in Central Australia, and that has obviously negative connotations in terms of local multipliers, both in generating work for other businesses and in directing employment.

Obviously, if you accept the arguments, as I do, of the impact of a GST on the construction industry, then the situation will be exac erbated by the imposition of a GST. I think that is absolutely indefensible. I am concerned that this Minister for Central Australia has absolutely no understanding or comprehension of the nature of the Alice Springs economy or of what this will mean.

But it is particularly important when we understand that the main driver of economic activity around Central Australia is the tourism industry. This is demonstrated by not only the work which is being done by the Alice Springs Town Council, but also work which has been published recently by the Northern Territory government called The Face of Alice Springs in Ten Years Project. This is a clear demonstration that the government has no plan for the future development of Alice Springs or the tourism industry.

Yet when we criticise it or criticise this governmentâ€”that is, the Howard governmentâ€”for its poor planning in relation to these issues and particularly in relation to the potential impact of a GST on tourism, we get a stone wall of silence in relation to the attitudes of Northern Territory ministers about how we expect them to defend the Northern Territory's interests against the negative impact of a GST. The Alice Springs economy and employment in Alice Springs relies heavily upon the tourism industry. And I am concerned thatâ€”
Mr Lloyd interjectingâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”It needs to be understood that the ignoramus opposite has absolutely no understanding of the Alice Springs economy.
â€”I take offence at that comment and I ask the member to withdraw.
â€”In the interests of the debate, the member for the Northern Territory may care to withdraw the remark. I do not believe it to be unparliamentary.

â€”I will withdraw, Mr Speaker, but thin-skinned fools should know better, and this is a thin-skinned fool who should know better. It highlights the embarrassment that those opposite have as a result of the GST. This is the point: they are not prepared toâ€”
â€”I really do not think the term `thin-skinned fool' is parliamentary and I do take offence. I ask the member to withdraw it.

â€”All members in the chamber know that there has been a general effort on all sides to raise standards. I believe that the member for the Northern Territory was unwise to enter into that area, although it is not unparliamentary. I call him to complete his speech.

â€”I am happy to, Mr Speaker, but it just highlights and emphasises my point not only about the Minister for Central Australia but also about the CLP government in the Northern Territory and the ignorance of this governmentâ€”the government of Mr Howardâ€”in relation to these issues. What they have done is demonstrate very clearly that they do not care about the impact of a GST on tourism in Central Australia. I might point out that the select committee on the impact of a GST on tourism in the Northern Territory said we would lose around 2,000 jobs. Are you saying that will not happen? It is very clear that it will. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Sun Metals Zinc Refinery: Industrial Action

talk.start.para: â€”I think it is unfortunate that the kind of language we heard earlier ever needs to be said in this place. I think the people of Australia do want better standards and I congratulate you, Mr Speaker, on trying to improve the standards of this place.

speech.para: I rise to congratulate the Townsville Chamber of Commerce this evening in relation to their media release today. The Townsville Chamber of Commerce, by way of a public statement today, have come out in respect of the strike at the Korea Zinc site at Townsville. The crippling strike is doing so much damage to Australia and the economy of my city. Normally the Townsville Chamber of Commerce would adopt an impartial role, so it is highly unusual for them to make the kind of statement that they have today, and they have made it in good faith. It is a damning indictment of the Labor state government and also of Labor members who represent electorates in the Townsville area. The Townsville Chamber of Commerce said that they were:

. . . highly critical of the lack of leadership from the Premier Mr Peter Beattie and indeed the State Government representatives in Townsville, Mike Reynolds and Lindy Nelson-Carr. Instead of paving the way for resolution of the Sun Metals dispute, two elected representatives have been supporting the picket line with blatant disregard for the law and the direction of the Industrial Commissioner, Mr Adrian Bloomfield. Mr Reynolds claims the law is unworkable. How can that be? Is it simply that Mr Reynolds doesn't agree with the law?

We have two Labor members supporting the picket line. In particular, Lindy Nelson-Carr has joined the picket line. It is an illegal picket line. I think it is unfortunate that members of state parliament should in fact be supporting an illegal action. It is the same as we saw in the Gordonstone coalmine dispute when another state Labor member was arrested for an illegal action in the picket line. The media release goes on:

The Chamber President, Fay Barker, claimed Mr Reynolds was all smoke and mirrors and had not faced up to the fact that the law has directed a return to work. The Chamber questions the ethics of elected representatives who denied or did not uphold the law and continued to dispute the direction of the Commissioner. Lindy Nelson-Carr was named as the Mother Theresa of all picket lines in State Parliament last night.
I, for one, find that most unfortunate. This is an indictment of the governance of the state of Queensland and the representation of our local members. The chamber said:
Rather than represent the people of Mundingburra, Lindy Nelson-Carr has elected to deny the law and maintain her place alongside the CFMEU and BLF in their picket line.

The real heroes in this debate are those who this afternoon will be attempting to break that picket line to get back to work. I note that the member for Townsville, Mike Reynolds, stated in the Bulletin of 25 March that the dispute is the result of unworkable industrial relations laws introduced by state and federal coalition governments. Also, in the state parliament today, the Premier said:
